webTitle: Everton v Tottenham - as it happened | Evan Fanning

fields.bodyText: Good evening everybody. So what's going wrong with Tottenham? Since the media began their courting of Harry Redknapp for the England job (a display of servile fawning that would put Daily Express report on Kate Middleton to shame) Spurs have fallen off the wagon somewhat. Sure, there was a 5-0 thrashing of Newcastle in there but defeats in their next two league matches, contributing to a run of only two wins in six, and suddenly Tottenham are looking anxiously over their shoulder at their north London rivals Arsenal who are coming up on the rails like a rabid zombie from 28 Days Later intent on feasting on the blood of third place. Glorious, glorious third place. Of course, there is also a chance that none of that is relevant and that Tottenham have merely lost their last two games because of a desperately poor 55 minutes against Arsenal and a mugging by Manchester United at White Hart Lane. But that doesn't suit the insatiable thirst for a narrative which goes world beaters-crisis-world beaters-crisis and what is certain is that a defeat today and people will be looking very hard at Spurs while tut-tutting and shaking their heads. And they certainly don't want that. And defeat is very much a possibility. Everton have beaten Manchester City and Chelsea at Goodison already this season and are currently in the midst of their best spell of the campaign, with no defeats in seven in the league. In fact they were last beaten in the league by Tottenham on 11 January in a fixture re-arranged from the opening day of the season after some yoofs around Tottenham decided they wanted some blu-ray players last August and wrecked the place. David Moyes celebrates 10 years in charge of Everton on Wednesday which begs the question: why would anyone want to spend 10 years at Everton? But in a climate where most manager's last about as long as it's taken you to read this sentence, a decade at a Premier League club which has largely been spent under a financial cloud that has been raining down gloom is quite some doing. Victory today would be an ideal way to celebrate the achievement and, slightly ironically, would lead to another wave of speculation that Moyes is the man to replace Redknapp if and when Harry does one for England. 5.09pm: David Moyes and Moe Syzlak. Have they ever been seen in the same room? Probably not. Anyway, back to the serious matters. Gravely serious matters. It is football, after all. Here are the teams ... Everton: Howard; Neville, Heitinga, Distin, Baines; Coleman, Osman, Fellaini, Drenthe; Cahill; Jelavic. Subs: Mucha, Hibbert, Jagielka, Stracqualursi, Gueye, Rodwell, Anichebe. Tottenham: Friedel; Walker, Kaboul, King, Assou-Ekotto; Bale, Sandro,Parker, Modric; Adebayor, Defoe. Subs: Cudicini, Van der Vaart, Saha, Kranjcar, Rose, Livermore, Nelson. Referee: Mark Halsey (Lancashire) 5.10pm: "Re: Spurs' recent decline," writes Mark Cruise. "I think there might be a few other factors at play - Since Saha arrived - he had a good game vs Newcastle, which has prompted 'Arry to play a 4-4-2. Most of Spurs success has come with a sort of 4-4-1-1, with Bale and Lennon wide, and Van Der Vaart sitting behind the striker. He seems to have abandoned that recently, and Bale seems to have abandoned playing wide altogether." No Saha today - he's on the bench - it's Jermain Defoe who is upsetting the balance with his low centre of gravity and his long-range shots. 5.24pm: And back to the real business. Regarding Moyes and Moe, Alex Hanton says: "I always thought Moyes looked like what McNulty from the Wire would look like had he actually spent 20 years as a hardened Baltimore detective instead of hanging around RADA working out and exfoliating." Fair enough, but what Simpsons character is closest to 'Arry. Mayor Quimby? 5.26pm: Howard Kendall is in the "posh seats" according ESPN. I thought there was no push seats at Goodison. If Moyes was to move on maybe Everton could put Kendall back in charge. After all, if Dalglish can go back to Liverpool ... 5.28pm: "I was going to object your reference to zombies in 28 Days Later," says Ian Copestake, "but instead it made me think that, well, they are the dead come to life so they could technically be zombies. They just run about a lot more. Sort of like Charlie Adam." 5.32pm: "I don't know about Harry, but I always thought Martin Jol was a dead ringer for Superintendent Chalmers," says Mark Cruise. Don't you mean SuperNintendo Chalmers? You're right though, you don't know about me. Peeep!!!!! Everton get us underway playing from right to left. Bale starts on the right for Spurs, Modric out left. 2 min: A loose pass from Heitinga leaves Osman floundering and Bale pounces, sprints down the right. Distin does well to shepherd Bale onto his right-foot where he doesn't look entirely comfortable and Distin manages to block his cross. 4 min: Moyes has switched Coleman to the left to counter-act the threat of Bale but the Irishman's first involvement is as an attacking threat as he cuts inside but drags his shot from the edge of the area wide of Friedel's post. "Am I right to think that if Everton win tonight, Tuesday's derby is a battle for position?" asks Gary Naylor, who is correct, obviously. "What a present that would be for David Moyes." 7 min: It's a fairly flat opening to the game. Both sides seem slightly unbalanced by having wide players whose first instinct is to cut inside. If they would only swap ... but what do I know? Anyway, more Simpsons chatter from Steven Hughes: "If 'Arry takes the England job he'll end up like The Simpsons' Gil soon enough." 10 min: AB, who is one letter away from being a very rich ex-Chelsea manager, writes: "the posh seats at Goodison are the ones obstructed by the posts when Everton play everyone's favourite 4-6-0 formation. it's the reason they didn't play Jelavic for ages after buying him - forwards are too risky!" 12 min: Bale's pass it cut out by Baines who finds the debutant Jelavic who shows the skills which made him such a hit in the SPL, in so far as he turns one way, then the other, then trips over the ball and gives it away. 14 min: Nothing much happening. This game is making me hungry. "Arry as Frank Costanza?" asks Ryang via the Twitter machine. "Or George's boss Kruger?" You mean this man? 18 min: Spurs have the first real chance of the game as the Everton defence opens up in front of the Defoe, who saunters into the area and is about to pull the trigger with his left foot but Heitinga gets back well to put him off and the shot ends up somewhere near the corner flag, which is probably where a Jermain Defoe left-footed shot would have ended up even without a challenge. 20 min: The best chance of the game and it comes to Fellaini who latches on the Jelavic's nod down and fires a left-footed half-volley from a tight angle which Friedel saves with his foot. Goal! EVERTON 1-0 Tottenham (Jelavic 22) Everton have the lead and it's Jelavic, on his full debut, who has the goal. Baines picked out Osman on the edge of the Spurs box with a drilled pass. Osman skipped by Kaboul, who needlessly threw himself into the challenge, and had the wherewithal to spot Jelavic and cut the ball back. The Croatian produced a fine side-footed finish, first time, low into the corner. Great strike. 27 min: There hasn't been a huge amount from Spurs in the way of a response. At least not from the players. The emails are little more animated. "Is it possible we're back in a position where Redknapp doesn't actually know what his best formation or best line up is?" asks Enna Cooper. "He doesn't seem to like making those kind of decisions and tends to just preserve of the status quo any time there's a tough choice to be made. It took injuries to other players for him to work out that Modric was wasted out wide and that we were better playing 4-4-1-1. He was initially determined that Bale should be a fullback, possibly just so he had one less midfielder to accommodate in the formation. Signing Saha and (possibly temporary) resurgence in form from Defoe seems to have thrown him and it feels as if he's gone back to his default 4-4-2 simply to avoid having to decide which of our three strikers to play. Imagine how confused he'll be if the gets the England job." 28 min: Free kick to Spurs about 30 yards out and a significant proximity to the touchline. That doesn't bother Bale who fires goalwards and for a moment it looks like it might swerve just inside Tim Howard's post but in the end the Everton keeper watches it drift wide. "I knew the second you mocked Jelavic he would score today," says Ryan Jones. "Please direct further ire toward goal-shy Tim Cahill and Tony Hibbert, the latter of whom has never scored for Everton despite playing 14,823 games for the club." It sounds like you're mocking me, Ryan? Maybe I'll do something good in a minute. I doubt it. 33 min: Sandro gives away free kick and Jelavic nearly does something else quite spectacular. He curls the free kick over the wall and Friedel has to scamper across goal and claw it away. It was actually a fairly comfortable save for Friedel in the end. 40 min: Harry may have to break his gentleman's agreement with David Moyes over Louis Saha's involvement if he wants to get back in this game. Spurs are toothless going forward, which makes sense if you imagine scoring a goal as taking a bite out of a massive hamburger. Bale shoots from the edge of the box but it barely reaches Tim Howard in the Everton goal and Defoe was in the way and offside anyway. 41 min: A brief glimpse of a way back into the game for Spurs. Everton make a bit of a mess of dealing with a free kick and the ball reaches Sandro at the back stick but his cross-shot is blocked behind. 44 min: Emmanuel Adebayor crashes into the advertising hoardings and Arsenal fans everywhere break into a smile. Phil Sawyer has been hard at work "So in decreasing order of animation we have 1. Charlie Adam, 2. (possible) zombies, 3. the game and 4. MBMers emails? I fear for your circulatory system, Evan. When Charlie Adam's the most exciting thing to think about that kind of low level of stimulation could be coma inducing." That hamburger mention will keep me going for a bit, I reckon. 45 min: One minute of added time. For those in the back that's one minute of added time. Half time: Everton 1-0 Tottenham. Jelavic's fine strike gives David Moyes's side a deserved lead at half time. Spurs have looked about as interested as a vegetarian in a steak house. I'm going to take a five minute break to contemplate all my important life choices up until this point. Half time emails. Gary Naylor brings some love for the man they call 'Moyesy': "After ten years running Everton on a hand to mouth basis, can David Moyes be hailed as the best decision-maker in the Premier League? Every week he has to decide whether to emphasise attack or defence, every week he has to assess the benefit of fielding players carrying knocks in a wafer-thin squad and every transfer window calls for shrewd deals in and out. Over all that time, his errors are remarkably few." Meanwhile Pete Coles brings the pain for the man he calls 'The Hibster': "I'm not actually watching this game, so maybe he's playing a blinder, but I've always wondered how Tony Hibbert has made it as a (regularly selected) premier league footballer. Is it just me? I've no wish to pick on the man for the sake of it, but seriously, isn't he just quite, well, rubbish?" Half time enlightenment. I decided not to come to any conclusions about my own life choices but instead focused all my anger on the quirky-song advert. They really are the worst thing humanity has ever had to endure. That's not overstating it, is it? If they contain coloured bouncing balls they're even worse. More Spurs ire. Rob Sheppeck says: "As a Spurs fan, I have to say that if this is the start of 'the wheels coming off phase' and we finish below arsenal again I'm going to have to stop watching football. I know we normally finish second best but to get my hopes this far up only to dash them is one disappointment too many." On David Moyes, Simon Glinn quips: "I fail to see how anyone who accepts a job working for Everton can be nominated as a good decision maker, let alone "the best in the Premier League" Peeep!: We're underway in the second half. No changes, either tactically or in personnel, from Tottenham. Perhaps a change in approach, however, as they're straight onto the attack with Defoe testing Howard from them the edge of the area. 47 min: "How's Mr Drenthe playing for Everton?" asks Shaun Thompson in tepid Alicante. "When he played here last year for Hércules, he went from hero to zero quicker than he was once clocked by the Alicante Rozzers for speeding along the sea-front with a very-refreshed lady in the passenger seat. A good, jinksy player when he could be bothered, would be my verdict. Yours?" We haven't seen an awful lot of jinksy from him tonight but saying that he's done more than Spurs' nominal wide men, Modric and Bale. 49 min: Spurs look a bit more of a threat this half as Parker robs Coleman and lobs the ball over the top to Defoe. he cuts inside, and tries an audacious left footed shot which ends, up, as earlier, somewhere near the corner flag. Still no tactical change from Redknapp. Sticking Modric out on the left has shades of Scholes being plonked there England. It smacks of having them in the team for the sake of it. 53 min: The best chance of the game for Spurs and again it's fallen to Defoe. He makes a diagonal run onto Parker's straight pass, takes a touch and settles himself before shooting with his left. Howard stays big and blocks the shot and gathers after the ball rebounds off Heitinga. 54 min: Louis Saha comes on for Emmanuel Adebayor. Harry breaks his non-legally binding gentleman's agreement. Do the FA want that kind of person in charge of England? "Tony Hibbert is rubbish," confirms Gary Naylor, "but he is disciplined, reads the game well and works hard for 90 minutes. That shouldn't be enough, but it is. Ask Phil Neville." 57 min: Spurs are really coming into this now. Bale hammers a perfect cross-field pass to Assou-Ekotto, whose drilled cross should be cut out by Fellaini but he mis-controls, Modric gathers, and hits a half-volley just over the top. "I don't know why, but whenever I hear Drenthe, I can't help but think of Creme de Menthe," says Chris Dunn. Thanks for that, Chris. It's probably because they rhyme. 59 min: Tottenham win a fortuitous corner after Defoe handled, but Bale's delivery is terrible and the ball sails over everyone and out of play on the far side. Which leads nicely to Sasu Laaksonen's email: "Bale, The most (press) overrated player in the league at the moment? A bit like 'Arry Redknapp in the managerial front." 61 min: A yellow card for Assou-Ekotto and Everton have a free kick in a dangerous area. It's swung in by Baines towards Fellaini but Spurs scramble the threat away. On Twitter, @kawatabake writes: "Re: Pete Coles ant-Hibbertism, Hibbert is a good defender and if he scores there will be amazing scenes. So he should play." 62 min: Yellow card for Defoe for knocking Heitinga over off the ball. I'm not sure how Jermain Defoe knocks over Heitinga but there you go. Coleman catches Sandro right on the edge of the area and this is a really good shooting position for Spurs. It's maybe a little too close so they'll have to go for power ... 63 min: ... yep it's power alright, as Kaboul hoof it with great power high into the stand. "Gary makes an interesting point about Moyes' lack of errors in decision making," says Phil Sawyer. "Merseyside seems to have a bit of a yin/yang thing going on at the moment, given that Dalglish's errors of judgement since returning have, what with one thing and another, been worryingly high (I say this a Liverpool supporter)." 64 min: Royston Drenthe comes off and Jack Rodwell is on. Re: Drenthe rhyming with Menthe, Matthew Walker says: "As a speaker of Dutch, I can assure you they don't rhyme." You're not saying it right, Matthew. 66 min: "Half hour to save our season, really Evan," says Steve Waterhouse. I'm not sure if that's a question laced with sarcasm or a statement. If I had to put money on it I'd go with the latter. I'll stick £50 on it. Boy, this is exciting. 67 min: Parker tries to slide in Saha but Distin sticks out a foot and deflects the ball into Defoe's path. His shot from the edge of the area takes a deflection which takes the pace off the shot (which was probably going wide anyway) and Howard saves. "If Harry needs to pick a new formation every match, does that mean his players' skill sets (ignoring injuries) are so narrow they're only good for one thing?" asks Paul Taylor. " I could imagine Pep G. moving his X all over the field to no discernible detriment." 70 min: Van der Vaart is on for Sandro as Redknapp again ignores how lopsided his side are. Saha bundles his way into the box but his stabbed shot catches Distin right in the kisser. 71 min: Everton counter-attack and the ball is squeezed out to Osman on the right. He's in acres of space, takes his time, but fires at the near post rather than across goal and Friedel beats the ball away. 73 min: The Spurs fans are apparently singing "Gareth Bale, he plays on the left." Their next song can be, "Luka Modric, he's best in the hole." Rick Buur emails about Royston Drenthe: "For Shaun Thompson in Alicante: I seem to remember that Drenthe fell out of favour because he was the only of the Hercules players who had the guts to speak up against the crooked owners who didn't pay the wages. While the other weasels chose to stay silent, the fans turned against the wrong party. Also he is as mad as a box of frogs." 77 min: Tottenham have the ball in the net but the flag is up for offside! It's the right decision. It was horrible defending from Rodwell, who sliced his clearance. The ball came off Bale's chest into the path of Defoe, who was two yards offside. He put it in the net but it won't count. 78 min: Everton make another change as the goalscorer Jelavic departs - he's faded as the game has gone on, understandably - and Stracqualursi is on. 79 min: Yellow card for Heitinga for a poor challenge on Bale. It's another decent position for Spurs ... Bale floats a cross to the back stick where King rises but nods wide. "In response to Mr. Sheppeck," says Ben Ricerson. "To the contrary, this will be the most edifying of seasons for all Spurs fans. Like England, it is typical of Tottenham to build up expectation before crushing it mercilessly; on the evidence of the past few weeks, it would appear that it is finally time for, as you say, "the wheels to fall off." The bittersweet taste of humiliation and failure will never be so vivid as long as we continue to disappoint!" 82 min: Moe Syzlak makes his final change as Phil Jagielka comes on for Seamus Coleman. "It's all very well to criticise HR's tactics," says Alistair Hann. "It's a popular pastime for fans who think themselves able to deliver damning judgement on the tactical aptitude of a man who has spent nearly 50 years in the game - but who one earth would they play on the left instead of Modric? Kranjcar is the only player in the squad capable of filling in and he simply doesn't bring the required workrate. Fact is, we don't have huge strength-in-depth out wide. And we don't have the money to sign top players as cover in those positions." 86 min: Stracqualursi slides on late on Walker which probably should have been a yellow but he gets away with it. On that note, Phil Sawyer writes: "Did Moyes send Stracqualursi on just to test your spelling at the end of a long working day?" Three words Phil: Copy-And-Paste. 7.18pm: Redknapp makes his final change as Jake Livermore is on for Captain Scotty Parker or, if you prefer, Smithers to Harry's Mr Burns. 89 min: King is judged to have fouled Stracqualursi in the centre circle which gives Everton a moment's respite. "Incidentally, it was probably a mistake to loan out Pienaar," says Alistair Hann. "He was the one player we did have who could provide good cover for the left." 89 min: Osman hangs out a leg and Bale goes over it. Osman thinks he's dived and has a few words with Bale but there probably was contact (just). And anyway, hanging out a leg in front of Bale is like dangling a piece of meat in front of a dog. What do you expect to happen? 90 min: Fives minutes of added time. I don't know where that came from. 90 + 1 min: Assou-Ekotto hangs in a cross from the left which King meets but he gets under it and Howard can gather. 90+2 min: Van der Vaart shoots from the edge of the area - it takes a massive deflection and loops onto the roof of the net with Howard helpless. Everton are hanging on. 90+3 min: Louis Saha hits the post! It was Assou-Ekotto's shot from the edge of the area. It deflected into Saha's path inside the six-yard box. He spun on his left-foot and fired off the post. It rebounded off Howard's knee and away to safety. Full time: Everton 1-0 Tottenham. The ball is launched into the area one last time but Howard gathers and hoofs clear and that is that. A huge win for Everton and (arguably) an even bigger defeat for Spurs. 7.27pm: That's three defeats in a row for Tottenham and they are in a real battle not only for third but possibly even for a top four finish. Expect the calls for Redknapp to decide on his future one way or another to get louder and louder this week. Not that that is necessarily the problem, but hey ho, that's how it goes. What a win for Everton who are flying going into a week where they can leapfrog Liverpool with victory at Anfield on Tuesday and have an FA Cup quarter final against Sunderland next Saturday. That's it from me. Thanks for all your emails. Apologies, but there was far too many to publish them all. Click here for the latest Premier League table. Bye!

"I think there might be a few other factors at play - Since Saha arrived - he had a good game vs Newcastle, which has prompted 'Arry to play a 4-4-2. Most of Spurs success has come with a sort of 4-4-1-1, with Bale and Lennon wide, and Van Der Vaart sitting behind the striker. He seems to have abandoned that recently, and Bale seems to have abandoned playing wide altogether." No Saha today - he's on the bench - it's Jermain Defoe who is upsetting the balance with his low centre of gravity and his long-range shots.

5.24pm: And back to the real business. Regarding Moyes and Moe, Alex Hanton says: "I always thought Moyes looked like what McNulty from the Wire would look like had he actually spent 20 years as a hardened Baltimore detective instead of hanging around RADA working out and exfoliating." Fair enough, but what Simpsons character is closest to 'Arry. Mayor Quimby?

5.26pm: Howard Kendall is in the "posh seats" according ESPN. I thought there was no push seats at Goodison. If Moyes was to move on maybe Everton could put Kendall back in charge. After all, if Dalglish can go back to Liverpool ...

5.28pm: "I was going to object your reference to zombies in 28 Days Later," says Ian Copestake, "but instead it made me think that, well, they are the dead come to life so they could technically be zombies. They just run about a lot more. Sort of like Charlie Adam."

5.32pm: "I don't know about Harry, but I always thought Martin Jol was a dead ringer for Superintendent Chalmers," says Mark Cruise. Don't you mean SuperNintendo Chalmers? You're right though, you don't know about me.

Peeep!!!!! Everton get us underway playing from right to left. Bale starts on the right for Spurs, Modric out left.

2 min: A loose pass from Heitinga leaves Osman floundering and Bale pounces, sprints down the right. Distin does well to shepherd Bale onto his right-foot where he doesn't look entirely comfortable and Distin manages to block his cross.

4 min: Moyes has switched Coleman to the left to counter-act the threat of Bale but the Irishman's first involvement is as an attacking threat as he cuts inside but drags his shot from the edge of the area wide of Friedel's post. "Am I right to think that if Everton win tonight, Tuesday's derby is a battle for position?" asks Gary Naylor, who is correct, obviously. "What a present that would be for David Moyes."

7 min: It's a fairly flat opening to the game. Both sides seem slightly unbalanced by having wide players whose first instinct is to cut inside. If they would only swap ... but what do I know? Anyway, more Simpsons chatter from Steven Hughes: "If 'Arry takes the England job he'll end up like The Simpsons' Gil soon enough."

10 min: AB, who is one letter away from being a very rich ex-Chelsea manager, writes: "the posh seats at Goodison are the ones obstructed by the posts when Everton play everyone's favourite 4-6-0 formation. it's the reason they didn't play Jelavic for ages after buying him - forwards are too risky!"

12 min: Bale's pass it cut out by Baines who finds the debutant Jelavic who shows the skills which made him such a hit in the SPL, in so far as he turns one way, then the other, then trips over the ball and gives it away.

14 min: Nothing much happening. This game is making me hungry. "Arry as Frank Costanza?" asks Ryang via the Twitter machine. "Or George's boss Kruger?" You mean this man?

18 min: Spurs have the first real chance of the game as the Everton defence opens up in front of the Defoe, who saunters into the area and is about to pull the trigger with his left foot but Heitinga gets back well to put him off and the shot ends up somewhere near the corner flag, which is probably where a Jermain Defoe left-footed shot would have ended up even without a challenge.

20 min: The best chance of the game and it comes to Fellaini who latches on the Jelavic's nod down and fires a left-footed half-volley from a tight angle which Friedel saves with his foot.

Goal! EVERTON 1-0 Tottenham (Jelavic 22) Everton have the lead and it's Jelavic, on his full debut, who has the goal. Baines picked out Osman on the edge of the Spurs box with a drilled pass. Osman skipped by Kaboul, who needlessly threw himself into the challenge, and had the wherewithal to spot Jelavic and cut the ball back. The Croatian produced a fine side-footed finish, first time, low into the corner. Great strike.

27 min: There hasn't been a huge amount from Spurs in the way of a response. At least not from the players. The emails are little more animated. "Is it possible we're back in a position where Redknapp doesn't actually know what his best formation or best line up is?" asks Enna Cooper. "He doesn't seem to like making those kind of decisions and tends to just preserve of the status quo any time there's a tough choice to be made. It took injuries to other players for him to work out that Modric was wasted out wide and that we were better playing 4-4-1-1. He was initially determined that Bale should be a fullback, possibly just so he had one less midfielder to accommodate in the formation. Signing Saha and (possibly temporary) resurgence in form from Defoe seems to have thrown him and it feels as if he's gone back to his default 4-4-2 simply to avoid having to decide which of our three strikers to play. Imagine how confused he'll be if the gets the England job."

28 min: Free kick to Spurs about 30 yards out and a significant proximity to the touchline. That doesn't bother Bale who fires goalwards and for a moment it looks like it might swerve just inside Tim Howard's post but in the end the Everton keeper watches it drift wide. "I knew the second you mocked Jelavic he would score today," says Ryan Jones. "Please direct further ire toward goal-shy Tim Cahill and Tony Hibbert, the latter of whom has never scored for Everton despite playing 14,823 games for the club." It sounds like you're mocking me, Ryan? Maybe I'll do something good in a minute. I doubt it.

33 min: Sandro gives away free kick and Jelavic nearly does something else quite spectacular. He curls the free kick over the wall and Friedel has to scamper across goal and claw it away. It was actually a fairly comfortable save for Friedel in the end.

40 min: Harry may have to break his gentleman's agreement with David Moyes over Louis Saha's involvement if he wants to get back in this game. Spurs are toothless going forward, which makes sense if you imagine scoring a goal as taking a bite out of a massive hamburger. Bale shoots from the edge of the box but it barely reaches Tim Howard in the Everton goal and Defoe was in the way and offside anyway.

41 min: A brief glimpse of a way back into the game for Spurs. Everton make a bit of a mess of dealing with a free kick and the ball reaches Sandro at the back stick but his cross-shot is blocked behind.

44 min: Emmanuel Adebayor crashes into the advertising hoardings and Arsenal fans everywhere break into a smile. Phil Sawyer has been hard at work "So in decreasing order of animation we have 1. Charlie Adam, 2. (possible) zombies, 3. the game and 4. MBMers emails? I fear for your circulatory system, Evan. When Charlie Adam's the most exciting thing to think about that kind of low level of stimulation could be coma inducing." That hamburger mention will keep me going for a bit, I reckon.

45 min: One minute of added time. For those in the back that's one minute of added time.

Half time: Everton 1-0 Tottenham. Jelavic's fine strike gives David Moyes's side a deserved lead at half time. Spurs have looked about as interested as a vegetarian in a steak house. I'm going to take a five minute break to contemplate all my important life choices up until this point.

Half time emails. Gary Naylor brings some love for the man they call 'Moyesy': "After ten years running Everton on a hand to mouth basis, can David Moyes be hailed as the best decision-maker in the Premier League? Every week he has to decide whether to emphasise attack or defence, every week he has to assess the benefit of fielding players carrying knocks in a wafer-thin squad and every transfer window calls for shrewd deals in and out. Over all that time, his errors are remarkably few."

Meanwhile Pete Coles brings the pain for the man he calls 'The Hibster': "I'm not actually watching this game, so maybe he's playing a blinder, but I've always wondered how Tony Hibbert has made it as a (regularly selected) premier league footballer. Is it just me? I've no wish to pick on the man for the sake of it, but seriously, isn't he just quite, well, rubbish?"

Half time enlightenment. I decided not to come to any conclusions about my own life choices but instead focused all my anger on the quirky-song advert. They really are the worst thing humanity has ever had to endure. That's not overstating it, is it? If they contain coloured bouncing balls they're even worse.

More Spurs ire. Rob Sheppeck says: "As a Spurs fan, I have to say that if this is the start of 'the wheels coming off phase' and we finish below arsenal again I'm going to have to stop watching football. I know we normally finish second best but to get my hopes this far up only to dash them is one disappointment too many."

On David Moyes, Simon Glinn quips: "I fail to see how anyone who accepts a job working for Everton can be nominated as a good decision maker, let alone "the best in the Premier League"

Peeep!: We're underway in the second half. No changes, either tactically or in personnel, from Tottenham. Perhaps a change in approach, however, as they're straight onto the attack with Defoe testing Howard from them the edge of the area.

47 min: "How's Mr Drenthe playing for Everton?" asks Shaun Thompson in tepid Alicante. "When he played here last year for Hércules, he went from hero to zero quicker than he was once clocked by the Alicante Rozzers for speeding along the sea-front with a very-refreshed lady in the passenger seat. A good, jinksy player when he could be bothered, would be my verdict. Yours?" We haven't seen an awful lot of jinksy from him tonight but saying that he's done more than Spurs' nominal wide men, Modric and Bale.

49 min: Spurs look a bit more of a threat this half as Parker robs Coleman and lobs the ball over the top to Defoe. he cuts inside, and tries an audacious left footed shot which ends, up, as earlier, somewhere near the corner flag. Still no tactical change from Redknapp. Sticking Modric out on the left has shades of Scholes being plonked there England. It smacks of having them in the team for the sake of it.

53 min: The best chance of the game for Spurs and again it's fallen to Defoe. He makes a diagonal run onto Parker's straight pass, takes a touch and settles himself before shooting with his left. Howard stays big and blocks the shot and gathers after the ball rebounds off Heitinga.

54 min: Louis Saha comes on for Emmanuel Adebayor. Harry breaks his non-legally binding gentleman's agreement. Do the FA want that kind of person in charge of England? "Tony Hibbert is rubbish," confirms Gary Naylor, "but he is disciplined, reads the game well and works hard for 90 minutes. That shouldn't be enough, but it is. Ask Phil Neville."

57 min: Spurs are really coming into this now. Bale hammers a perfect cross-field pass to Assou-Ekotto, whose drilled cross should be cut out by Fellaini but he mis-controls, Modric gathers, and hits a half-volley just over the top. "I don't know why, but whenever I hear Drenthe, I can't help but think of Creme de Menthe," says Chris Dunn. Thanks for that, Chris. It's probably because they rhyme.

59 min: Tottenham win a fortuitous corner after Defoe handled, but Bale's delivery is terrible and the ball sails over everyone and out of play on the far side. Which leads nicely to Sasu Laaksonen's email: "Bale, The most (press) overrated player in the league at the moment? A bit like 'Arry Redknapp in the managerial front."

61 min: A yellow card for Assou-Ekotto and Everton have a free kick in a dangerous area. It's swung in by Baines towards Fellaini but Spurs scramble the threat away. On Twitter, @kawatabake writes: "Re: Pete Coles ant-Hibbertism, Hibbert is a good defender and if he scores there will be amazing scenes. So he should play."

62 min: Yellow card for Defoe for knocking Heitinga over off the ball. I'm not sure how Jermain Defoe knocks over Heitinga but there you go. Coleman catches Sandro right on the edge of the area and this is a really good shooting position for Spurs. It's maybe a little too close so they'll have to go for power ...

63 min: ... yep it's power alright, as Kaboul hoof it with great power high into the stand. "Gary makes an interesting point about Moyes' lack of errors in decision making," says Phil Sawyer. "Merseyside seems to have a bit of a yin/yang thing going on at the moment, given that Dalglish's errors of judgement since returning have, what with one thing and another, been worryingly high (I say this a Liverpool supporter)."

64 min: Royston Drenthe comes off and Jack Rodwell is on. Re: Drenthe rhyming with Menthe, Matthew Walker says: "As a speaker of Dutch, I can assure you they don't rhyme." You're not saying it right, Matthew.

66 min: "Half hour to save our season, really Evan," says Steve Waterhouse. I'm not sure if that's a question laced with sarcasm or a statement. If I had to put money on it I'd go with the latter. I'll stick £50 on it. Boy, this is exciting.

67 min: Parker tries to slide in Saha but Distin sticks out a foot and deflects the ball into Defoe's path. His shot from the edge of the area takes a deflection which takes the pace off the shot (which was probably going wide anyway) and Howard saves. "If Harry needs to pick a new formation every match, does that mean his players' skill sets (ignoring injuries) are so narrow they're only good for one thing?" asks Paul Taylor. " I could imagine Pep G. moving his X all over the field to no discernible detriment."

70 min: Van der Vaart is on for Sandro as Redknapp again ignores how lopsided his side are. Saha bundles his way into the box but his stabbed shot catches Distin right in the kisser.

71 min: Everton counter-attack and the ball is squeezed out to Osman on the right. He's in acres of space, takes his time, but fires at the near post rather than across goal and Friedel beats the ball away.

73 min: The Spurs fans are apparently singing "Gareth Bale, he plays on the left." Their next song can be, "Luka Modric, he's best in the hole." Rick Buur emails about Royston Drenthe: "For Shaun Thompson in Alicante: I seem to remember that Drenthe fell out of favour because he was the only of the Hercules players who had the guts to speak up against the crooked owners who didn't pay the wages. While the other weasels chose to stay silent, the fans turned against the wrong party. Also he is as mad as a box of frogs."

77 min: Tottenham have the ball in the net but the flag is up for offside! It's the right decision. It was horrible defending from Rodwell, who sliced his clearance. The ball came off Bale's chest into the path of Defoe, who was two yards offside. He put it in the net but it won't count.

78 min: Everton make another change as the goalscorer Jelavic departs - he's faded as the game has gone on, understandably - and Stracqualursi is on.

79 min: Yellow card for Heitinga for a poor challenge on Bale. It's another decent position for Spurs ... Bale floats a cross to the back stick where King rises but nods wide. "In response to Mr. Sheppeck," says Ben Ricerson. "To the contrary, this will be the most edifying of seasons for all Spurs fans. Like England, it is typical of Tottenham to build up expectation before crushing it mercilessly; on the evidence of the past few weeks, it would appear that it is finally time for, as you say, "the wheels to fall off." The bittersweet taste of humiliation and failure will never be so vivid as long as we continue to disappoint!"

82 min: Moe Syzlak makes his final change as Phil Jagielka comes on for Seamus Coleman. "It's all very well to criticise HR's tactics," says Alistair Hann. "It's a popular pastime for fans who think themselves able to deliver damning judgement on the tactical aptitude of a man who has spent nearly 50 years in the game - but who one earth would they play on the left instead of Modric? Kranjcar is the only player in the squad capable of filling in and he simply doesn't bring the required workrate. Fact is, we don't have huge strength-in-depth out wide. And we don't have the money to sign top players as cover in those positions."

86 min: Stracqualursi slides on late on Walker which probably should have been a yellow but he gets away with it. On that note, Phil Sawyer writes: "Did Moyes send Stracqualursi on just to test your spelling at the end of a long working day?" Three words Phil: Copy-And-Paste.

7.18pm: Redknapp makes his final change as Jake Livermore is on for Captain Scotty Parker or, if you prefer, Smithers to Harry's Mr Burns.

89 min: King is judged to have fouled Stracqualursi in the centre circle which gives Everton a moment's respite. "Incidentally, it was probably a mistake to loan out Pienaar," says Alistair Hann. "He was the one player we did have who could provide good cover for the left."

89 min: Osman hangs out a leg and Bale goes over it. Osman thinks he's dived and has a few words with Bale but there probably was contact (just). And anyway, hanging out a leg in front of Bale is like dangling a piece of meat in front of a dog. What do you expect to happen?

90 min: Fives minutes of added time. I don't know where that came from.

90 + 1 min: Assou-Ekotto hangs in a cross from the left which King meets but he gets under it and Howard can gather.

90+2 min: Van der Vaart shoots from the edge of the area - it takes a massive deflection and loops onto the roof of the net with Howard helpless. Everton are hanging on.

90+3 min: Louis Saha hits the post! It was Assou-Ekotto's shot from the edge of the area. It deflected into Saha's path inside the six-yard box. He spun on his left-foot and fired off the post. It rebounded off Howard's knee and away to safety.

Full time: Everton 1-0 Tottenham. The ball is launched into the area one last time but Howard gathers and hoofs clear and that is that. A huge win for Everton and (arguably) an even bigger defeat for Spurs.

7.27pm: That's three defeats in a row for Tottenham and they are in a real battle not only for third but possibly even for a top four finish. Expect the calls for Redknapp to decide on his future one way or another to get louder and louder this week. Not that that is necessarily the problem, but hey ho, that's how it goes. What a win for Everton who are flying going into a week where they can leapfrog Liverpool with victory at Anfield on Tuesday and have an FA Cup quarter final against Sunderland next Saturday. That's it from me. Thanks for all your emails. Apologies, but there was far too many to publish them all. Click here for the latest Premier League table. Bye!
fields.trailText: Nikica Jelavic's first-half goal on his full debut condemned Tottenham to their third defeat in a row
fields.headline: Everton v Tottenham - as it happened

webTitle: Scottish round-up: Leigh Griffiths scores to seal Hibs win at Ayr United

fields.bodyText: Goals in the first half by Roy O'Donovan and Leigh Griffiths were enough to beat First Division side Ayr United and put Hibernian into the semi-finals of the Scottish Cup. O'Donovan, on loan from Coventry, had the ball in the Ayr net in the fourth minute at Somerset Park after Ivan Sproule's drive from 16 yards was spilled by Kevin Cuthbert, but the flag was up for offside. The travelling fans only had to wait two more minutes for the opening goal, though, when O'Donovan headed in a George Francomb free-kick. When the loanee from Norwich City whipped his delivery in from wide on the left it found O'Donovan unmarked drifting into the box and his header beat Cuthbert and went in off a post. In the 16th minute, after the Hibs defender Paul Hanlon fouled Keigan Parker wide on the right, the home side missed a great chance to draw level. Michael McGowan's free-kick was met by the Ayr defender Chris Smith only six yards out but he failed to make proper contact, allowing the goalkeeper Graham Stack to smother. Three minutes later Griffiths made it 2-0 from the penalty spot after the Ayr defender Andrew Geggan had fouled the Hibs midfielder Isaiah Osbourne at a corner. Such was the force of the penalty that it took the netting away from its support. ' Griffiths then missed a great chance to finish Ayr off when he raced clear on goal, only to slash his shot wide. The home side persevered, throwing bodies forward, but in the 76th minute Hanlon's header from a Francomb corner was cleared off the line by Jonathon Tiffoney, before Osbourne miscued in front of goal when he looked poised to score. There was a vociferous appeal for an Ayr penalty in the 82nd minute when the Hibs substitute Matt Doherty appeared to handle the ball as he fell in the area but the referee ignored the penalty claims. Ayr battled hard to get back into the game but, having given themselves too much to do after going behind so early in the game, ran out of steam. Hibs will look forward to Sunday's draw and also a semi‑final at Hampden Park. In the only Scottish Premier League fixture this weekend, Roman Golobart made amends for a spectacular own goal by scoring the equaliser in a 1-1 draw between Inverness and Kilmarnock. It was just reward for Inverness, who dominated at the Tulloch Caledonian Stadium. Inverness were better in the opening stages until the defender Golobart scored his second own goal of the season after 31 minutes. Danny Buijs struck an angled attempt from outside the penalty area high and wide as the visitors looked to add to their lead early in the second half. Shane Sutherland's rising shot from the edge of the penalty area was just over the crossbar for Terry Butcher's side. The Caley Thistle captain Richie Foran missed a gilt‑edged chance in the closing stages when his side‑footed effort from 10 yards was blocked by Cammy Bell. The keeper then tipped over Billy McKay's shot. But moments later after he denied Richie Foran's header, McKay found Golobart who scored from close range to level the scores with seven minutes remaining. Michael Nelson was picked out by Lee Johnson's free-kick but headed the ball straight at Esson as the two teams settled for a share of the points.
fields.standfirst:
• Hibs beat Ayr United in Scottish Cup quarter-final
• Inverness and Kilmarnock draw in the SPL

webTitle: Six Nations 2012: Ireland v Scotland - as it happened | Scott Murray

fields.bodyText: A cursory glance at the form book, and this should be a shoo-in for the home side. Ireland may not be what they were a couple of years ago, yet in this Six Nations have been a poor refereeing decision from beating all-conquering Wales, and should really have put France away in Paris last weekend. Scotland, on the other hand, are joint bottom of the table, after three defeats from three. Yet you never know. Scotland have had an extra week to rest since their last game, have some fine fresh talent coming through in Stuart Hogg and David Denton, and are steadily (if slowly) improving, to the point that they've managed to cross the try line in their last two matches. Well done, everyone! Also, the last time these two teams met in Dublin, the Scots clocked up a rare away victory. Dan Parks put in a man-of-the-match performance, and if that can happen, etc., and so on... Karma dept. Scotland are due a bit of good fortune, having played better than their results suggest. But then Ireland are in credit with Lady Luck too after the Wales debacle. Ireland are favourites, so shouldn't need it, but we'll see. These two sides often serve up better-than-decent entertainment, so: better-than-decent entertainment, please! Ireland: R Kearney (Leinster); T Bowe (Ospreys), K Earls (Munster), G D'Arcy (Leinster), A Trimble (Ulster); J Sexton (Leinster), E Reddan (Leinster); C Healy (Leinster), R Best (Ulster, capt), M Ross (Leinster), D O'Callaghan (Munster), D Ryan (Munster), S Ferris (Ulster), P O'Mahony (Munster), J Heaslip (Leinster). Replacements: S Cronin (Leinster), T Court (Ulster), M McCarthy (Connacht), S Jennings (Leinster), T O'Leary (Munster), R O'Gara (Munster), F McFadden (Leinster). Scotland: S Hogg (Glasgow Warriors); L Jones (Edinburgh), N De Luca (Edinburgh), G Morrison (Glasgow Warriors), S Lamont (Scarlets); G Laidlaw (Edinburgh), M Blair (Edinburgh); A Jacobsen (Edinburgh), R Ford (capt, Edinburgh), G Cross (Edinburgh), R Gray (Glasgow Warriors), J Hamilton (Gloucester), J Barclay (Glasgow Warriors), R Rennie (Edinburgh), D Denton (Edinburgh). Replacements: S Lawson (Gloucester), E Murray (Newcastle), A Kellock (Glasgow Warriors), R Vernon (Sale Sharks), C Cusiter (Glasgow Warriors), R Jackson (Glasgow Warriors), M Evans (Castres). Referee: C Pollock (New Zealand) Kick off: 5pm. The teams are out! Ireland are in green, Scotland in blue. That's how they roll. Incidentally, the Irish have been taking advice from Michael O'Leary, the grasping Ryanair footpad, who gave the team a motivational chat during the week. It's a wonder they're not stranded about 60 miles from the Aviva Stadium. Perhaps they'll charge Scotland £10 for every tooth they manage to knock out, £50+VAT per cauliflower ear. The anthems. They're singing them. And we're off! Greig Laidlaw gets the ball spinning - the thing won't roll - and Heaslip gathers. Scotland soon get the ball back, though, and will get the put-in at a scrum just inside the Irish half. A good minute or so is wasted with some tedious fannying around at the engagement. There goes that atmosphere! Lansdowne Road is as good as silent already. 3 min: After two minutes of faffing around, Scotland are awarded a free kick. They move the ball out wide left towards Hogg, and nearly set the youngster off down the wing, but there's a forward pass. However, Bowe has drifted offside looking for an intercept, and that's a penalty to Scotland. 4 min: PENALTY. Ireland 0-3 SCOTLAND. Laidlaw hauds his baws for a few seconds, like a smutty Jonny Wilkinson, then strokes a kick between the posts. Scotland have the early lead. 7 min: Earls responds with a chip and chase down the left. Laidlaw is under it, and although clattered by Earls, keeps possession, allowing Scotland to move upfield. They're seeing most of the ball, and throwing it around quite nicely at the moment. 9 min: They've made 38 passes compared to Ireland's four. The final one of those flies behind Hogg as they look to release Scotland's youngest starter for 40 years down the right. 10 min: PENALTY. Ireland 0-6 SCOTLAND. D'Arcy joins a ruck from the side. Nope. Penalty to Scotland, 30 yards from the posts, just to the left of the sticks. Laidlaw makes no mistake. The Scottish passing game isn't quite clicking, but it's been good enough; they've had all the possession, and this is a fair enough scoreline. Ireland are yet to turn up. I blame Michael O'Leary. 12 min: Turnover ball for Ireland just outside the Scottish 22, down the right. Ireland shuttle it out to the left, where a penalty's awarded, Rennie joining the ruck from the side. Will they kick? Nope. Sexton clips the ball into touch right by the left-hand corner. They've got a five-metre lineout, and really need points from this. 14 min: TRY. IRELAND 5-6 Scotland. And they get them! The lineout's won, O'Callaghan moves the ball to the left touchline, and captain Best powers through Blair and over into the corner. 15 min: CONVERSION. IRELAND 7-6 Scotland. Sexton steps up to take the conversion. He checks, turns, and begins again. Meanwhile Sean Lamont assumes Sexton's started his run, races out, in the style of that Zaire player at the 1974 Fifa World Cup, and hoofs the static ball upfield! Some light comedy. A cursory glance at the form book, and this should be a shoo-in for the home side. Ireland may not be what they were a couple of years ago, yet in this Six Nations have been a poor refereeing decision from beating all-conquering Wales, and should really have put France away in Paris last weekend. Scotland, on the other hand, are joint bottom of the table, after three defeats from three.

Yet you never know. Scotland have had an extra week to rest since their last game, have some fine fresh talent coming through in Stuart Hogg and David Denton, and are steadily (if slowly) improving, to the point that they've managed to cross the try line in their last two matches. Well done, everyone! Also, the last time these two teams met in Dublin, the Scots clocked up a rare away victory. Dan Parks put in a man-of-the-match performance, and if that can happen, etc., and so on...

Karma dept. Scotland are due a bit of good fortune, having played better than their results suggest. But then Ireland are in credit with Lady Luck too after the Wales debacle. webTitle: Liberal Democrats at war over Nick Clegg's plan for a 'tycoon tax'

fields.bodyText: The Liberal Democrats descended into open warfare over tax on Saturday as senior party figures reacted furiously to a call by Nick Clegg to back off their flagship plan for a "mansion tax" and push instead for a US-style "tycoon tax" on the rich. Clegg angered key figures close to the Lib Dem business secretary, Vince Cable, when he suggested the idea of a legally binding minimum rate of tax for "tycoons" was more of a priority than taxing homes worth over £2m. In a speech to the Lib Dems' spring conference in Gateshead, Cable stoked the row by making clear that he was still in favour of the mansion tax rather than the new Clegg plan, on which he is said not to have been consulted by the party leader. He told the conference: "We must insist on a radical plan for fair tax which we developed in opposition through the tax commission: lifting low earners out of tax and shifting the tax base from income to wealth, especially high-priced property." Cable also made a light-hearted reference to the "mansion tax" in his speech. "On Thursday, I was the guest of the lord mayor of London at a fine banquet in the City. And as I looked around the Mansion House, all I could think of was … tax," he said. The row is a severe embarrassment to the Lib Dems, who had hoped to use the conference to present a united front on tax ahead of the 21 March budget. The Lib Dems want the chancellor, George Osborne, to raise the tax-free threshold – initially to about £9,000, and then to £10,000-plus before the next election. In a speech to his party, Clegg is expected to say that "the budget in 10 days' time must offer concrete help to hard-pressed, hard-working families" through a "big increase in the income tax threshold further and faster towards £10,000". Lib Dems say the move could be paid for by higher taxes on the most wealthy, with Cable pressing for a tax on homes worth more than £2m. But Clegg shifted his ground when he announced his "tycoon tax" idea in an interview with the Daily Telegraph. He said hundreds of millionaires were paying a tax rate of less than 20% on their earnings by employing an "army of lawyers and accountants". The answer, he suggested, would be to enforce a legally binding minimum rate of tax – probably between 20% and 30%. But Lord Oakeshott, a former Lib Dem Treasury spokesman who is seen as Cable's mouthpiece, accused Clegg of floating an unworkable idea and of bypassing the party's established policy-making structures. "This is a superficially attractive idea that falls apart on close analysis," Oakeshott said. "It does nothing to catch non-doms or non-residents. The US system is quite different from ours. We worked for years to produce a fair and robust tax policy. You can't invent Lib Dem policy on the hoof in the Daily Telegraph." A senior Liberal Democrat source dismissed Oakeshott's concerns. He said: "I'm surprised it's him [Oakeshott] leading the defence of the tycoon tax dodgers. "We'll let the Treasury see if the policy is workable; they tend to know more than a former Treasury spokesman." In the past 10 days, the Lib Dems have indicated they would be prepared to accept a cut in the 50p top rate of income tax – a key demand of many Tory MPs – in return for a wealth tax. Chris Leslie, Labour's shadow financial secretary, said few people would take Clegg's calls for fairness on tax seriously while the coalition was hitting the poor with cuts to tax credits. "He is negotiating how to cut the 50p top rate of tax for the richest 1% while slashing tax credits by £73 per week for working couples on the minimum wage. And he is the man who campaigned against a regressive rise in VAT, but then announced a VAT hike just weeks after becoming deputy prime minister," Leslie said.

He told the conference: "We must insist on a radical plan for fair tax which we developed in opposition through the tax commission: lifting low earners out of tax and shifting the tax base from income to wealth, especially high-priced property."

Cable also made a light-hearted reference to the "mansion tax" in his speech. "On Thursday, I was the guest of the lord mayor of London at a fine banquet in the City. And as I looked around the Mansion House, all I could think of was … tax," he said.

The row is a severe embarrassment to the Lib Dems, who had hoped to use the conference to present a united front on tax ahead of the 21 March budget.

The Lib Dems want the chancellor, George Osborne, to raise the tax-free threshold – initially to about £9,000, and then to £10,000-plus before the next election.

In a speech to his party, Clegg is expected to say that "the budget in 10 days' time must offer concrete help to hard-pressed, hard-working families" through a "big increase in the income tax threshold further and faster towards £10,000".

Lib Dems say the move could be paid for by higher taxes on the most wealthy, with Cable pressing for a tax on homes worth more than £2m.

But Clegg shifted his ground when he announced his "tycoon tax" idea in an interview with the Daily Telegraph. He said hundreds of millionaires were paying a tax rate of less than 20% on their earnings by employing an "army of lawyers and accountants".

The answer, he suggested, would be to enforce a legally binding minimum rate of tax – probably between 20% and 30%.

But Lord Oakeshott, a former Lib Dem Treasury spokesman who is seen as Cable's mouthpiece, accused Clegg of floating an unworkable idea and of bypassing the party's established policy-making structures.

"This is a superficially attractive idea that falls apart on close analysis," Oakeshott said. "It does nothing to catch non-doms or non-residents. The US system is quite different from ours. We worked for years to produce a fair and robust tax policy. You can't invent Lib Dem policy on the hoof in the Daily Telegraph."

A senior Liberal Democrat source dismissed Oakeshott's concerns. He said: "I'm surprised it's him [Oakeshott] leading the defence of the tycoon tax dodgers.

"We'll let the Treasury see if the policy is workable; they tend to know more than a former Treasury spokesman."

In the past 10 days, the Lib Dems have indicated they would be prepared to accept a cut in the 50p top rate of income tax – a key demand of many Tory MPs – in return for a wealth tax.

Chris Leslie, Labour's shadow financial secretary, said few people would take Clegg's calls for fairness on tax seriously while the coalition was hitting the poor with cuts to tax credits. "He is negotiating how to cut the 50p top rate of tax for the richest 1% while slashing tax credits by £73 per week for working couples on the minimum wage. And he is the man who campaigned against a regressive rise in VAT, but then announced a VAT hike just weeks after becoming deputy prime minister," Leslie said.
fields.headline: Liberal Democrats at war over Nick Clegg's plan for a 'tycoon tax'
fields.trailText: Liberal Democrat conference split by accusations that deputy prime minister is making policy 'on the hoof'

webTitle: Wales emerge victorious in scrappy dress rehearsal for the big day | Eddie Butler

fields.bodyText: As early as the 18th minute, Wales were planting kickable penalties into the corner. The reward was a penalty from the passage of play that followed, a sitter that Leigh Halfpenny blasted over. The full-back makes no concession to distance, as if his intention is to kick the ball through the concrete bowl and out into central Cardiff. Rhys Priestland went for the corner again in the 21st minute, as if the spree was under way. The reward this time from the ensuing phases was a penalty to Italy and the score remained 6-3. Some spree. Italy were awarded a kickable penalty of their own in the 38th minute and opted to go for the corner themselves, as if they were trailing by so many that only clumps of points by the seven would help their cause. They came away with nothing and the score at half-time stood at 9-3. Some lost cause. Perhaps it was the sense of what was inevitably to come that persuaded both teams to force the issue of abandon. This was a game without foreplay, with Wales going through their entire repertoire of passing long, short, wide and narrow in the first minute alone. Barely had the ball landed from the kick-off than George North and Alex Cuthbert were bursting into midfield. Wales had all the ball, their failure at a couple of lineouts balanced by a pair of scrums when they shoved the Italian pack backwards. The only other threat to their absolute control of possession was the whistle of George Clancy, who was very strict about release at the breakdown and the body positions of those hitting the ruck. The case for taking the lineout before three points could be made by the wish for a higher rhythm. Quite why Italy were drawn into the corner game was less clear. The nearest they came to a break was at the start of the second half when Ian Evans dropped a pass and the visitors hoofed the ball downfield. Before that they had tried a couple of forward charges in midfield, only for Dan Lydiate to bowl over the ball-carrier. The No6 gave another outstanding display as the stopper in the back row. There had to come a time when he was not required in such all-consuming quantities. Alun Wyn Jones pounced on a stray ball and forced the turnover, and suddenly all the insistence on not stopping for breathers made sense. From the point of turnover Wales swept the ball wide, Jamie Roberts easing through a gap and leaving weary defenders behind. So far so good, according to the theory of how to beat Italy: keep on cranking up the speed until something gives. Now the final chapter could begin, piling on the pace and points. The finer points of the grand slam campaign are not quite as refined as the fitness levels of Wales. Their theories are not quite as imposing as their physical attributes. Referee Clancy had a part to play – he had a slightly exaggerated role here. Mirco Bergamasco, back on the wing and place-kicking duty, failed to catch a high ball. It bounced off his chest and he flapped at it with his right hand before it hit the ground. He made contact and Clancy, communicating with his touch judge, ruled it had not gone forward. The ball made its way to Halfpenny, who returned it even higher towards not Bergamasco but the mighty Sergio Parisse. Halfpenny ran and jumped and clattered into the Italian captain. The full-back was penalised and to compound the derision now aimed at Clancy, little Halfpenny, who barely comes to Parisse's knee, was sent to the sin-bin. In what was meant to be a dress rehearsal of celebration there was now an element of protest, as in the crowd expressing itself as Disgusted of Llandrindod Wells. The game turned scrappy, the sin-binning coinciding with all the replacements that come on the hour. Scott Williams made an impression, as he seems to do, and there was a first cap for scrum-half Rhys Webb. There were glimpses of the speed and wide range of skills of Justin Tipuric, but only flashes in the dying embers of an unsatisfactory occasion. That is, until Cuthbert converted the roars of protest into cheers. It meant the theory still stood and that speed and width would have their day. The theory of excitement and the reality of flatness in front of an irritated Millennium Stadium, pockmarked with empty seats. It does not matter. This was only a dress rehearsal and it will, according to another theory – that Wales on a roll and with a showdown at home are unstoppable – that all will be all fine on the day that does matter. Next Saturday is the one, when France come to town with the grand slam to play for and all the memories of Sam Warburton and the kicks that missed in the World Cup semi-final to be banished. Now that, unlike this, will be an occasion.

webTitle: France's Muslims hit back at Nicolas Sarkozy's policy on halal meat

fields.bodyText: Les Enfants Terribles, a chic restaurant in Paris's 12th arrondissement, was packed. Plates of halal foie gras à la maison, halal braised lamb with rosemary, and halal caramelised duck were being dispatched to tables. Fresh fruit cocktails and exotic non-alcoholic concoctions replaced glasses of wine. Mohamed Abdenebi, 36, a history and geography teacher, was a typical diner: young, French, Muslim, dynamic – and furious. According to Abdenebi, France has let its Muslim population down. "They said to us, 'Do your studies, and you will get a job.' We did our studies but there were no jobs and they said we hadn't done the right studies. Each time there was a new obstacle." Instead of being integrated and treated with equality, Abdenebi says the halal row shows the extent to which France's Muslims are being made to feel like "the enemy within". Similar complaints were being heard across France. President Nicolas Sarkozy's decision to make the labelling of halal meat pivotal to his re-election campaign has infuriated, alienated and dismayed France's Muslim community, which may number as many as six million, and the backlash is growing. Members of the booming educated and entrepreneurial Muslim middle class say they are tired of being cast as scapegoats in Sarkozy's wooing of the extreme right and have accused him of dangerous and divisive election tactics. Fateh Kimouche, a high-profile Muslim blogger, said the new class of second- and third-generation Muslims in France was not prepared to lie down and let the French republic roll over it as their parents had done. "My parents came from Algeria and, like many others, they didn't make a fuss because they felt like invited guests who had to be on their best behaviour. But I was born here. We are Muslims and we are French, but every day we are attacked, insulted and treated like terrorists or extraterrestrials," he said. "France educated us; we have energy and enthusiasm and we have brains, businesses and money. The old generation of politicians don't seem to realise this." The phoney war over halal meat erupted in February when Marine Le Pen, leader of the far-right Front National, claimed consumers were eating halal unknowingly. Sarkozy, trailing the Socialist frontrunner François Hollande, accused her of whipping up an artificial controversy. Shortly afterwards, with Le Pen snapping at his heels in the opinion polls, Sarkozy performed a volte-face. In spite of surveys showing that voters were less concerned about halal meat than they were about the weather and football, he announced it was "the issue that most preoccupies the French". For France's Muslims – already feeling victimised by a burqa ban, by controversial government-sponsored debates on national identity and by the outlawing of Muslims praying in the streets, a sight Le Pen likened to the Nazi occupation – it was a low blow. Few believed that the halal uproar had anything to do with how animals are slaughtered or who eats them. "It's a blatant attempt to divert attention away from the real problems," said Yanis Bouarbi, founder of the successful restaurant website paris-halal.com. "You can have a debate about how animals are killed, but this is pure electioneering." Kimouche, 36, who has a degree in political philosophy, worked as a publisher's proofreader before he spotted the untapped business potential in France's nascent Muslim middle class. He left his job and started a profitable blog, al-Kanz, which covers all aspects of Muslim life and rituals, and boasts up to 10,000 visitors a day. "Nicolas Sarkozy and Marine Le Pen have resorted to this because they have no solutions to the real problems. It's the last desperate thrashings of a mad dog that has nothing to lose," he said. "It's part of a chain of thought that goes from halal meat to Islamism to terrorism." As he talks, Kimouche finds it hard to hide his anger and frustration at what he sees as a "violent and populist" presidential campaign. "Really, we might have hoped for better from our politicians. I am a French Muslim, I love France, but I want to leave this country. Every day we are being attacked and insulted and we have had enough." In alienating Muslims such as Kimouche and Bouarbi, Sarkozy is ignoring the spending power – the halal market, for example, is growing at 20% a year more than organic food – of a socio-economic group that might otherwise have been tempted to vote for his business-friendly, free-market agenda. Kimouche points out that there is not one Muslim MP in the French parliament. "In France, they say there are no communities within the republic, everyone is the same. But this is not true. No matter what we do, no matter how hard we try, we are seen as a fifth column, the enemy within, a threat, a menace." France has failed to learn the lesson of its history, says Abdenebi: "In 1939 when there was an economic crisis, the enemy was the Jews. Today there is a crisis and it is the Muslims. It's the same discrimination, just a different community." Kamel Saidi, 34, the softly spoken owner of Les Enfants Terribles, says he finds the political atmosphere "revolting and tiring". And he cannot see the situation improving. "People feel afraid because today the party of the right is adopting the ideas of the extreme right. What's even more worrying is that this attitude is not going to change, certainly not in the near future. "It is depressing that all we are trying to do is find our place in society, and there is no recognition of this, just suspicion. Once again, it's as if the whole Muslim community is suspect." Abdenebi is slightly less pessimistic: "There is hope for change, but I don't see it happening for at least 50 years… maybe 100."

webTitle: Shirley Williams attacks critics over health bill at Lib Dem conference

fields.bodyText: Shirley Williams, the Liberal Democrat grandee, spoke on Saturday of her anger over personal attacks unleashed by opponents of the NHS reforms, as Lib Dem delegates dropped a vote on killing the health bill. She said she had been falsely accused of "stitching up" a deal to save the controversial bill and described how she was fighting an "uphill battle for the truth", challenging lies about the legislation on Twitter and the media. Baroness Williams, initially an opponent of the NHS reforms, has become a supporter in recent weeks following more than a thousand amendments in the Lords which she says have changed the bill "significantly". However, critics claim she has been used by the Lib Dem leadership to usher the bill into law. While delegates at the Lib Dem spring conference in Gateshead decided against voting on a "kill the bill" emergency motion, there is still considerable anger in the party. More than 270 delegates voted in favour of the "kill the bill" motion in a sign that will worry the deputy prime minister, Nick Clegg, as he tries to carry his party with him on the policy. Instead of the "kill the bill" motion, activists will vote on the alternative, backed by the leadership, which suggests the bill as amended should now be passed. Although it is possible that this motion could be defeated, this would be far less embarrassing for Clegg than a vote to drop the bill altogether. One of the most vociferous critics of the bill, Charles West, a former Lib Dem parliamentary candidate for Shrewsbury, said he believed Williams was wrong. "I think Shirley Williams is a very able politician, but she doesn't understand the NHS or the health bill," West said. He added that she had been persuaded that "it will all be fine" but that she was "wrong on the details". West's comments followed a row on Twitter in which party members accused the leadership of manipulating a "national treasure" to support the health bill. Williams responded by saying she was "against personal attacks" and believed her critics were "behind the facts" on the bill. Talking to delegates, she said: "We are fighting an uphill battle for the truth, to be able to base people's opinions on facts, and not on the stuff they have presented on Twitter and tweet and, dare I say it, the new social network, which is known as twist. "My view about the coalition, which is bloody difficult, is you get in very early on legislation you don't like which is why the prelegislative phase is very difficult. It is damned hard work but we know now we can change legislation out of all recognition." Williams also cited a column by the Guardian's Polly Toynbee as an example of the "tribalism trumping truth". Williams told a fringe meeting: "I have to say this morning I am extremely angry. Yesterday you may have read in the Guardian a story from Polly Toynbee which began with the following sentence: 'Yesterday Shirley Williams led her erstwhile rebels into the government lobby to vote for a hospital's rights to use 49% of beds for private patients.' "There has never been a right for hospitals to offer 49% of their places for private patients. The so-called 49% is a myth or, to put it in non-parliamentary language, a lie. "Now, I know Polly well. She's a very able journalist. Either she just did not look at the detail and therefore is able to say that in the Guardian, or she did look at the detail and decided that tribalism should trump truth." Williams added: "I want to see Polly Toynbee in the Guardian's Corrections and Clarifications column." On a visit to Siemens in Newcastle, Clegg said he hoped that the party would in time see what changes had been made to the health reforms and the need for legislation. He said: "I think it is quite right that people have a look at it. "My own view is that when people look at what we have done – rather than what we are alleged to have done, because many of the critics I speak to about the bill, when I ask them if they have read the health bill, they say they haven't – I think there is a big gap between what people think the bill is going to do and what it actually says." Paul Burstow, the Lib Dem health minister criticised by several colleagues for failing to halt the bill sooner, pleaded with activists to recognise that reform was needed because of a "postcode lottery" in the NHS. "What this legislation will do is cast a light on the system. It will save lives and reduce the amount of unnecessary disability and misery." However other senior members of the party continue to criticise the bill. John Pugh, a Lib Dem MP, said: "I know Nick Clegg says we should stop looking in the rear view mirror. But if you don't look in it sometimes you end up heading into more car crashes."

Paul Burstow, the Lib Dem health minister criticised by several colleagues for failing to halt the bill sooner, pleaded with activists to recognise that reform was needed because of a "postcode lottery" in the NHS.

"What this legislation will do is cast a light on the system. It will save lives and reduce the amount of unnecessary disability and misery."

However other senior members of the party continue to criticise the bill.

John Pugh, a Lib Dem MP, said: "I know Nick Clegg says we should stop looking in the rear view mirror. But if you don't look in it sometimes you end up heading into more car crashes."

webTitle: Mystery bird: orange-flanked bush-robin, Tarsiger cyanurus | GrrlScientist

fields.bodyText: Orange-flanked bush-robin, Tarsiger cyanurus (synonyms, Luscinia cyanura, Nemura cyanura and Ianthia cyanura; protonym, Motacilla Cyanurus), Pallas, 1773, also known as the red-flanked bluetail or sometimes as the white-breasted blue wood-chat, photographed in Hong Kong, a Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. Image: Marie-Louise Ng, 11 February 2012 (with permission, for GrrlScientist/Guardian use only) [velociraptorise]. Nikon D7000 Question: This small Chinese mystery bird is showing up in the most unlikely places all over the world. Why? Can you identify this bird's taxonomic family and species? Is it male or female? Response: This is an orange-flanked bush-robin, Luscinia cyanura, probably a first-winter male. This small insectivorous songbird is migratory, wintering mainly in northern Asia, India and Taiwan. They breed in mixed coniferous forests of northern Asia and northeastern Europe, all the way from Finland to Kamchatka and into Japan. Their breeding range is expanding. They'e recently been showing up in Great Britain, and are now are popping up in western Alaska, too. This is a cavity-nesting species. They nests in holes in bank sides or under tree roots or logs. The female lays up to four pale blue eggs per clutch. Orange-flanked bush-robins are shy, often remain hidden, even whilst singing. Here's a nice audio recording of a singing male orange-flanked bush-robin, accompanied by a photograph (recorded in Lieksa, Pohjois-Karjala, Suomi/Finland; uploaded 10 January 2010): Visit kuujussi's YouTube channel [video link]. The female orange-flanked bush-robin has olive-brown upperparts, white throat, orangish-red flanks, a bright blue rump and tail. Her bill is black and there is a thin white ring around her black eyes. The male has brilliant blue upperparts and often a pale blue or blue-grey supercilium, but otherwise, resembles the female. Here's an informational video accompanying footage of a female orange-flanked bush-robin (filmed in Taiwan, uploaded 10 December 2010): Visit hikasiaorg's YouTube channel [video link]. The taxonomy of this species is confusing. The orange-flanked bush-robin is often placed into the genus, Tarsiger, although its placement is dependent upon whom you are arguing with at the moment since it appears that the authorities are more or less equally split regarding this bird's relationships. Tarsiger is a genus comprising six species of passerines in the taxonomic family, Muscicapidae (Old World flycatchers). These birds are small, mostly brightly coloured insectivorous birds native to Asia and northeastern Europe; and most of them are reside in the mountains. Even though Tarsiger forms a distinct monophyletic group, it is sometimes subsumed into the related genus Luscinia. Luscinia is a genus comprising eleven species of nightingales and their relatives, also in Muscicapidae. There is a lot of overlap between these two taxa, which some authorities merge. Further, as if that isn't confusing enough, authorities have long been confused as to precisely where Luscinia ends and another genus, Erithacus, begins. In fact, a number of taxa were dumped into one genus or the other, or the Luscinia was merged into Erithacus. The one thing that appears consistent is that the orange-flanked bush-robin was never been placed into Erithacus. But the confusion regarding the placement of the orange-flanked bush-robin extends beyond its generic placement, too. Originally, the orange-flanked bush-robin and its close relatives were placed into the thrush family Turdidae, although these birds are now thought to be chats (subfamily: Saxicolinae) that are part of the Old World flycatcher family.
