Obviously, from a Marxist point of view, it isn't – we all make mess, we all have to eat, we all have to look after children if we have them. When some of us refuse to do any of that ourselves, others among us will end up doing all of it. And this has wider ramifications than just some people having to do a lot of mopping; cleaning and childcare have very low status in this society and, I'm sure, many others.

Catherine Spencer is 41, has a degree, and used to manage 200 people. She now cleans her local primary school. "There's a governors' meeting – they were coming in as I was leaving this evening," she says. "They see me in my little sky-blue tabard and they immediately think of me as a complete idiot. It amuses me, but I can see that someone else would be deeply offended." Elodie Guttierez, 38, is a nanny – she is actually my nanny, and we'll come to this later – and she concurs: "If you've got a group of people talking about what they do, when you say you're a nanny, nobody asks you anything. They think, 'Poor her, she's just a stupid girl.' A guy in the Groucho actually turned his back on me when I told him what I did."

This delegation of labour is not consequence-free, in other words. On one side, the modern urban life is shaped by a particular economic view in which your work is a huge part of your identity. This credo of fulfilment by industry is actually not very realistic – it isn't as stark as the idea that preceded it, historically speaking, where your worth was determined by your wealth and breeding. But in its way, it's just as exclusive – in a world that believes your worth is your work, a lot of people aren't going to feel very valuable. Second, there is this peculiarly low status accorded to household chores.

Adam Smith's classic explanation was: how can you respect work that, once it's done, instantly needs doing again? As he put it, "menial tasks and services … generally perish in the instant of their performance and seldom leave any trace or value behind them". But that doesn't quite do it for me – office cleaners do the same job, and may be held in the same low regard. But there isn't the taint of shame. The novelist and poet Kate Clanchy wrote a book, Antigona and Me, about her Kosovan cleaner, and someone (a childless person; I think this is relevant) said to her: "I would never have a cleaner." She remembers replying "But you do! Who cleans your office?"

Personally, I think the problem is a background belief that household work is women's work – it's shameful because we're outsourcing not just our laundry, but the building blocks of our femininity. And there's always some reason why the work of women is outside calculable value. If it's dusting, it's too trivial and evanescent for money; if it's giving birth, it's too important and lasting. It might be a systematic attempt, since the dawn of money as the unit of exchange, to keep women from having any independent agency in the market. Or it might be a coincidence.

Leaving the feminist dimension aside for a second, this presents a problem, doesn't it? When, in the act of employing someone, you erode their standing in the world, that's quite a complicated relationship. Stella McCartney told The Sunday Times Style magazine this week: "I have a housekeeper and a nanny, although I find that word jarring. I tell her, 'I just want to call you a friend.'" That's a typically nice-person response – she finds the word jarring because of the chasm of status it implies. But changing the word is insufficient. The chasm still exists; when someone at the Groucho asks her housekeeper what she does for a living, she's not going to reply: "I'm Stella McCartney's friend."

There are less nice people who deal with this discomfort by simply pretending the person doesn't exist. Eye-contact crops up again and again: Helen, a 37-year-old PhD student who cleaned for people when she was doing her BA, tells me about a woman who used to hold out the bin bag and not meet her eye. Someone else she worked for left her Filofax on the side one day: "And I thought, 'I wonder what section she's put me in?' Am I under H, for my name, or am I under C for cleaner? And I was under C for cleaner. I was so offended. I don't know why, but in the context of how she was treating me overall, it was as though I was less than human." There's obviously something very difficult about employing another human for work that is private – so employers attempt either to play down the employment, a la McCartney, or play down the human.

Or there's a third way, which is to recast the domestic worker as someone with a very specific skill, which might not be very high-status but nevertheless isn't universal, so it's not something you could do yourself – like a ratcatcher or a handyman. For her book, The New Maids – Transnational Women and the Care Economy, Helma Lutz interviewed both cleaners and employers, and noted dryly: "Employers like to see their domestic workers as service providers; it is largely a form of exculpatory rhetoric which conveniently diverts the debate away from relations of power and dependence, since the (academically) educated upper-middle-class clients will usually know that they are not party to a legally safeguarded service-provider contract."

People used to deal better with the political hazards of all this: my mother and father were with a cleaning agency in the late 50s, which specifically signed up people such as art students and unemployed actors – almost all men – so that you could get your cleaning done by someone who might need the money, but was part of the bohemian class, as well as the male hegemony. The act of picking up your pants wouldn't disturb their place in the world, or sense of themselves. My parents worked for a couple who probably would have done their own cleaning, except that they were also fighting South African apartheid. I mean, if you want to be a liberal but you hate washing up, you can't get much more copper-bottomed than that. However, here the bonds between Marxist theory and socially responsible practice really break down: if you're so squeamish about the relations of power and dependence that you will only employ people in or above your own class, that, to the untrained eye, will look a lot like open snobbery. What if there's a working-class person or a migrant or a single mother who is prepared to overlook the status anxiety because they could really do with the money? Are you still going to stick to your out-of-work actors agency then?

I feel theoretically guilty about having a nanny, but I don't actually feel guilty. This is partly because Elodie is framed in my mind as a "service-provider"; that is, she does it because she's better at it than I am. This is demonstrably true, and furthermore, anybody who thinks childcare is "menial" and therefore isn't extremely demanding intellectually, physically and emotionally simply hasn't done enough of it. Naturally, though, if I didn't have a job I'd just have to get better at it. So there's some exculpatory rhetoric going on there.

But there's also a feminist point – I don't see why it should be me outsourcing my maternal duties. We're delegating our parental duties as a family, and if I were to accept that all the guilt and shame from that act are mine, I would be effectively rolling back the crucial point of feminism: that we're as well suited to the workplace, and ill-suited to the home, in any proportion, as any given man. Cleaners are a bit different – the "service provider" case is hard to make, since even if you are useless at it, you're presumably good enough to uphold your own standards. And it is boring; you can't pretend to think someone else is feeling fulfilled by it. But the feminist case is even stronger here. Considering the huge advances made by women in the workplace, perhaps not with boardroom representation, but certainly with equal pay, it is astonishing that so little progress has been made domestically. The British Household Panel Survey looked at 5,000 families over 15 years and found that single men do four hours of housework a week, while single women do seven hours. But married and cohabiting women do 12 hours a week, and men suddenly do 40 minutes. This is not just about women having higher standards, in other words (I know I don't); it is about a resolute failure to import principles of equality into the home. Many of us have commissioned out the conflict to someone in a (possibly metaphorical) sky-blue tabard.

The overwhelming downside of all this vexed morality and shame is that the entire business is chased underground and cleaners are treated appallingly. This is particularly the case when they're migrants, especially those whose immigration status is uncertain. Two of the most lingering details of the rape accusation made against Dominique Strauss Kahn in New York last year were these: firstly, while the case collapsed for a number of reasons, the fact the alleged victim didn't have proper residency especially harmed her credibility, certainly in the trial-by-media; uncertain immigration status redounds unimaginably badly upon your rights as an employee, and as a human being. Secondly, when fellow maids held a rally in New York, their stories threw up a snapshot of the contempt in which they are held. One woman remembered a hotel guest who'd put the "make up my room" sign up, but was sitting naked on a chair when she walked in.

A study in 2003 found there are European estimates that one in four domestic workers is employed illegally. A report on socio-economic conditions in Germany found that "the private household is by far the sector with the highest proportion of unprotected, illegal employment" – and there's no reason, certainly no regulation, to make us think the UK is any different. People think of cash-in-hand work as getting one over on the tax man; domestic labour is an illustration of the fact that, when you are employed outside the legitimate tax system, the overwhelming likelihood is that someone else is getting one over on you.

You're outside minimum-wage legislation, you have no job security, you have no holiday or sick pay; someone I knew whose cleaner came on a Monday used to discharge her without payment on bank holidays. Her rationale was that the cleaner didn't pay national insurance contributions, so why should she get the benefit? It did not even occur to her that she wasn't paying employer contributions, either.

Helma Lutz pans out to form a fascinating historical trajectory of domestic service – from a serf class three centuries ago, through the "professionalisation" of service two centuries ago when unions introduced some basic rights, contracts, days off, that kind of thing. After that, in the late-19th and early- to mid-20th centuries, men's wives became all the domestic help they needed; and finally, the emancipation of women has taken domestic work back, not to that professionalised era, but to the era before it, when workers had no rights, no contracts under law, no career progression and no public visibility. Lutz wonders whether this amounts to a "refeudalization".

In short, the first thing to do is to break the embarrassment of domestic help down into its constituent parts: it is one thing having a cleaner and feeling embarrassed about it, because you should be doing it yourself; it is another thing having a cleaner and feeling ashamed because you offer no job security and no holiday pay and no contractual equity of any sort. It's all a bit of a fail, but you can always fail better.
fields.headline: A cleaner conscience: the politics of domestic labour
fields.trailText: Zoe Williams: Domestic work is a grubby business. There is a huge, unseen workforce who do our mopping, cleaning and childcare. But this delegation of labour is not consequence-free

webTitle: Demands to speed up the adoption process could be short-sighted | Deborah Orr

fields.bodyText: Like Tony Blair before him (as is so often the case), David Cameron is urging local authorities to speed up the adoption process. Like Tony Blair before him, he'll find that this is more easily said than done. It is true that many people complain of the long period of vetting they undergo before they are allowed to adopt. But the reasons for this are not all the consequence of "PC gone mad" by any means. The trouble is that in a lot of cases the children who need adoptive parents are already quite traumatised by the time things get to that stage. Adoptive parents need to be very tough and very committed. It is not so very unusual for an adoption to fail, and much of the cautiousness that social workers employ is in an effort to avoid the possibility of a child experiencing a second devastating family breakdown. When politicians call for the adoption process to be speeded up, they are identifying a symptom of another difficulty – which is that very few babies are put up for adoption at birth. It would seem fairly brutal, a call to speed up the process whereby infants are removed from their natural parents. Anyone who watched BBC2's superb recent three-part documentary, Protecting Our Children, will understand that while even saying such a thing is hard enough, actually doing it is a very difficult, solemn and serious undertaking indeed.

webTitle: The fall and rise of BBC 6 Music

fields.bodyText: BBC 6 Music which faced the axe two years ago celebrates its 10th anniversary on Sunday, and will mark the decade next Friday with an event at London's Southbank Centre. The celebration which features Laura Marling, Public Image Limited, De La Soul and Blur's Graham Coxon, finds the digital radio station in relatively rude health, its listener figures put at nearly 1.5m, double what it was achieving in February 2010, when the BBC proposed to close the station, a decision that was revoked by the trust five months later. Indeed, so successful was the campaign to save it – which involved protests by listeners and the arrival at the BBC of a deputation from the British Phonographic Industry headed by the former EMI boss Tony Wadsworth – that some felt the closure had been manufactured as a publicity stunt. "A lot of people think it wasn't going to close, but it really was," says Lauren Laverne, whose mid-morning show broke the news of the reprieve, playing Lambchop's Up With People to celebrate. "It was a horrible time. I don't think any of us thought we'd be reprieved. My producer did, but he's the world's most ridiculous optimist. I was sure that was it." Even so, there is a sense that the threat of closure was the best thing that happened to 6 Music, and not merely because it raised awareness of its existence among a public who seem to have liked what they heard and stuck around. Its controller Bob Shennan says it galvanised a station with a turbulent and muddled history: as presenter Stuart Maconie notes wryly, "there's nothing like the threat of imminent closure to focus the mind". Launched with the vague and spirit-sapping remit of "archive and album tracks", it struggled to find an identity and a listenership. "Nobody knew what it was or where it was. It was a step into the unknown," says Gideon Coe, a 6 Music DJ since the launch, who remembers presenters having to be given digital radios so that they could listen to the station they worked for. "You'd hear some people going, it's a station that falls between Radio 1 and Radio 2 and other people going, no, that's not what it is at all. There was confusion and the figures were pitifully low." In an attempt to snare more female listeners, the former controller Lesley Douglas appointed TV presenter George Lamb as mid-morning DJ – the comic Viz subsequently ran a cartoon strip comparing Lamb to a character called Terry Fuckwitt, whose brain had been removed and replaced with a piece of dog excrement – with Douglas stoked further controversy by claiming that women would enjoy Lamb's show because of his "less intellectual approach". Today, devotees would claim that the Southbank line-up barely scratches the surface of 6 Music's eclecticism, particularly with the spirit ofMaconie's Freak Zone, a bold attempt to subject Sunday teatime listeners to what Maconie describes as "records no other radio show would play – free jazz, prog rock, electronica, novelty records, soundtracks". It's the kind of show that would have been lost, Maconie thinks, had the station closed, despite the BBC commission's belief that 6 Music was occupying territory that commercial radio stations were already covering:. "You could put it out as a podcast, or have me broadcasting it pirate-radio style from the top of a tower block, but I don't know," he said. Instead its combination of affable presenting and wildly esoteric music seems to be spreading. Over the course of last Sunday, 6 Music's DJs played tracks by dubstep auteur Skream, Black Sabbath, Basic Channel, King Oliver's Creole Jazz Band, the Muppets, a "dark ambient" track by Crosswinds called From The Bogs Of Aughiska, Roland Kirk, the Monkees and a group of traditional musicians from the Solomon Islands remixed by dub producer Manasseh. "There's something to be said for things that aren't commercial, that are about protecting the integrity of the artistic landscape," says Laverne. "That sounds pretentious – you'd never throw that into a link on the radio – but it's a sentiment behind what we do. Because we don't have to do it to the satisfaction of a sponsor and an advertiser, we have more freedom." But for all the increased listenership and eclectic output, 6 Music's continued existence is not something greeted with untrammelled delight. "It's spoonfeeding a generation that don't need spoonfeeding. They can go out and find it on the internet," offers one industry figure, who feels the BBC's money would be better spent on the World Service than "satisfying the cravings of middle-aged music fans". "There was a time when there was very little broadcast media, when John Peel was the only route to a certain type of music. "Now, you can find an infinite amount of music on the internet and radio stations around the world. I don't think it's specialist enough to make it necessary." Although you could possibly apply the same argument about the internet to every music-based radio station, there remains a perception that 6 Music caters primarily to a certain kind of male listener in their late 30s, a state of affairs perhaps compounded by the number of Britpop-era pop stars on the presenters' roster: Cerys Matthews, Jarvis Cocker, Laverne, Fun Lovin' Criminals' Huey Morgan. It's perhaps worth noting that every 6 Music presenter contacted for this piece felt it necessary to dispel that view, without prompting. "I think some people think it's all indie guitar music which it isn't," offers Maconie. Those who protested about its closure, he says, "were different kind of people to the ones everyone had thought. It wasn't just a few blokey music obsessives sitting atop teetering piles of old Sounds and Melody Makers from the 70s and 80s. There were a lot of women. There were a lot of ordinary people who just wanted something a bit different from their music and their presenters." Certainly, everyone concerned seems buoyant about 6 Music's future: the jazz and dance DJ Gilles Peterson is about to join "broadcasting during daylight hours", notes Shennan, "which I'm sure will come as a shock to his system". Coe said: "It's got to square the circle between being adventurous and esoteric and appealing to enough listeners to justify its existence. "But if 6 Music didn't exist, a lot of music would be lost. Not just new stuff, old things as well. I can't see anyone else playing Container Drivers by the Fall."

webTitle: This week's new events

fields.bodyText: Masters Of Dirt, London & Manchester Like a latterday Evel Knievel show, the globetrotting Masters Of Dirt tour brings both skill and stunts in a visual spectacular that makes even monster trucks look dull. Here, fireworks shoot from the handlebars of bikes both petrol and pedal-powered, and riders perform aerial gymnastics, seemingly only vaguely in contact with their machines. It's fast-paced and jaw-dropping, with freestyle tricks on motorbikes, BMX, mountain, mini and quad bikes, and even a snowmobile. Perfect vicarious thrills, in other words. Wembley Arena, Wed; Manchester Arena, Fri Katrina Dixon History Of Taxidermy, London With a subtitle that promises art, science and bad taste, this lecture on the art and the history of stuffing or mounting dead animals for pleasure and profit should provide a fascinating insight into an almost-lost art form. Dr Pat Morris will hold forth on the business side of filling Fido with sawdust and deliver a history of Walter Potter, whose Museum of Curiosities held a stunningly odd collection of dioramas of stuffed squirrels, kittens and frogs undertaking very human leisure pursuits. Everything from pet cats to hunting trophies and museum elephants will be covered in the evening salon. 11 Mare Street, E8, Tue Iain Aitch Garden Re-Leaf Day, Nationwide We've got Comic Relief and Sports Relief; now Garden Re-Leaf (get it?) is urging gardeners across Britain to wield their spades for worthy causes. Celebrity gardening quizzes, wheelbarrow races and miniature garden contests will be hosted. World records for seed-sowing and "the biggest ever cream tea party" will be attempted, while schoolchildren take on a mass potato-planting scheme. Take part in a Pot-on-athon in Woodborough, design your own wishing tree leaf in Preston, or invent an outlandish horticultural headpiece at a botanical Mad Hatters' Day in St Albans. Various venues, Tue Colette Bernhardt Out & about South Tyneside International Magic Festival, South Shields, Sat & Sun Watch magicians from around the world, and learn tricks at close-up sessions and masterclasses. Customs House, Mill Dam Festival Of Literature, Oundle, Sat to 18 Mar Alexander McCall Smith stars, plus musical comedy from Mitch Benn, kid lit events and a Poetry Takeaway van. Various venues Science Festival, Cambridge, Mon to 25 Mar Guest directed by Robin Ince, this boasts over 180 events, mostly free, on the theme of "breaking boundaries". Various venues StAnza, St Andrews, Wed to 18 Mar Poetry, plus films, music, theatre, talks, workshops and kids' events. Various venues The Edible Garden Show, Nr Coventry, Fri to 18 Mar Experts offer tips on growing your own and keeping bees and goats. Oh, and pig Olympics. Stoneleigh Park

webTitle: This week's new theatre and dance

fields.bodyText: The Master And The Margarita, London The return of the superb Complicite to the Barbican is always a cause for joy. Following Shun-kin and A Disappearing Number, Simon McBurney's company offers an adapation of the cult Soviet novel The Master And Margarita, the complex plotting of which is dominated by the figure of the Devil, who wreaks havoc as a professor of black magic in Stalinist Russia. Written by Mikhail Bulgakov (being played by Alex Jennings in Collaborators at the National) in the years before his death in 1940, and only published in 1967, the vivid characters alone should provide plenty for Complicite's innovative style to feast on. webTitle: This week's new exhibitions

fields.bodyText: Jean Dubuffet, London In old age the great mischief-maker Jean Dubuffet said his early works' punch was bound to the brief, historical moment it had provoked. Whether inspired by art by prisoners, children or the mentally ill to create zany images of politicians, cyclists and jazz musicians, or experimenting with concrete or butterfly wings, his paintings gave occupied and postwar Paris a jolt. This show offers insight into the last hurrah of his late years, from 1975 to 82, with previously unexhibited works from five major series. Théâtres De Mémoire, for example, sees Dubuffet create a tangled patchwork of wobbly figures from the swimming scribbles of the earlier Lieux Abrégés series that capture memory's jumble. By the time of his penultimate series, Mires (Sights), the scrawled people or buildings have dissolved into bright abstractions, while the final series, Non-Lieux (Cases Dismissed) is all brutal, densely worked lines. Waddington Custot Galleries, W1, to 14 Apr Skye Sherwin Minerva Cuevas, Manchester Renowned Mexican artist Minerva Cuevas uses old magic lanterns and 19th-century microscope projectors to evoke an era of almost alchemical scientific research into the workings of nature, human nature and the age-old troubled relationship between the two. It's a kind of video magic realism where humankind's desire to understand and control the wilderness of chaotic natural forces underpins our social culture. Yet nature also becomes as much a commodity to be advertised, indulged in and exploited against a backdrop of threatening extinctions. While such stuff is the basis of so much eco-concerned contemporary art, Cuevas invests it all with an air of ambivalent wonderment, as her 16mm film, Landings, takes us on a trip through the history of civilisation, into a mysterious past and uncertain future. Cornerhouse, to 25 Mar Robert Clark The Crisis Commission, London Some of the biggest names in contemporary art – including Tracey Emin, Antony Gormley and Yinka Shonibare – have contributed to this fundraising show, ending in an auction, for the homeless charity Crisis. What's more, with the exception of Sir Anthony Caro's gift, it's all new, specially commissioned work. Caro, the titan of postwar sculpture and original heavy metal boy, has donated his 1984 work Down Centre, a prone steel figure with bound feet that suggests the harshness of modern urban life. Meanwhile there's double-edged street talk rendered in neon from Emin. Further artists on the bill include cult cartoonist David Shrigley and the video artist Gillian Wearing, whose confessional portraits of ordinary folk have often taken place on the street. Somerset House, WC2, Wed to 22 Apr SS James Benning, Sunderland Veteran film-maker James Benning returns to his hometown of Milwaukee to update his highly influential 1977 work One Way Boogie Woogie. If you like your films with flashy effects, stay away from Benning's spoilsport subversions. Not much at all happens in his work, but that is the whole deadpan point. By focusing on backstreet details, Benning tricks us into an unprecedented perspective on the great American road movie. Northern Gallery For Contemporary Art, to 9 Jun RC Franz Erhard Walther, London Works such as Three Broad Bands graced conceptual art's landmark shows of the 1960s, his chums include Gerhard Richter, and he's taught the likes of Martin Kippenberger. Yet, outside Germany, Franz Erhard Walther is one of his generation's lesser-known names. Perhaps that's because, as groundbreaking as his interactive work is, it's resolutely quiet and humble. In this first UK show, a retrospective of his work is joined by his recent autobiographic graphic novel, The Dust Of Stars, an epic 500 pages of personal and public history. The Drawing Room, SE1, to 28 Apr SS Michael Day, Sheffield Michael Day's video installations are a strange mix of Romantic metaphysical alienation and the superficial connection offered by global communications. Dreamlike seascapes and mountainous landscapes are upset by blatant gadgetry. A radio mast drifts in and out of vision amid clouds and snowfall, the mast's red warning light flashing alarmingly and the sequence building a sense of loneliness. Yet, as the film fades, the viewer realises that the light is in fact a small LED inset into the projection screen. Mainstream cinema engages in entertaining reveries, but Day's work gives us an artifice that is perversely heartening. Bloc Projects, to 24 Mar RC Keith Vaughan, Chichester Originally an illustrator by trade, the Sussex-born postwar artist Keith Vaughan absorbed many lessons from the modern masters. An early painting of yellow cornfields where labourers puff pipes sings of Cézanne, the mask-like faces his nudes wear recall the cubist Picasso, while Matisse presides over the flat, rhythmic forms and colours of his later works. Vaughan's theme throughout, however, was personal. His painting of a naked man huddling in a cave might be seen in relation to Henry Moore's famous image of bodies sheltering from the Blitz in the underground. It seems less though about the violence of war than about the challenges of being gay in an era that was far from out and proud. His great subject was man, usually nude, in nature, yet his paintings play down the erotic element, seducing the viewer instead chiefly through their palette of washed out clouds, lush fields, pale stones and cold seas. Pallant House, to 10 Jun SS Jeremiah Day, Sheffield Through a series of combinations of photographs, videos and audio recordings, Jeremiah Day builds up research into documentary subjects, the true significance of which remains elusive. His multiple perspectives focus in such peculiar disconnected detail on significant locations that the whole procedure takes on an air of cryptic allegory, as Day seeks out psychogeographic sites of political resistance. For him, buildings resound with historic stirrings and political hauntings. Of All Possible Things, his first UK solo exhibition, tackles the unresolved legacies of the cold war, focusing on a former Berlin Wall checkpoint that's now a Lidl supermarket. Site Gallery, to 14 Apr RC

webTitle: DJ DVA Q&A

fields.bodyText: The track I'll be opening my next DJ set with DVA: Reach The Sun I'll be coming on after Untold, so I'll need a long and emotional intro to reset things. If he plays his new tune last, I'll have problems – it's sick. The track that currently gets the most rewinds Dismantle: Computation I've seen people do some cracked-out skanks to this tune. Skream is one of those people. He dances like he's just been electrocuted with 1,000 volts. It's too funny, you should see it. The track that's been unfairly slept on this year Funk Bias: Last Forever I used to batter it! It was released on the Swamp81 label which normally gets a lot of love, but this release just got tumbleweed. The track that got me out of bed this morning Shy One: Bedknobs & Boomkicks It's a project I'm releasing on my label DVA Music. It had me up at 4.30am this morning trying to get her to finish it off. The track I wish I'd signed to my label Cher Lloyd: Swagger Jagger Then I would have made sure that no one else on the planet heard it apart from her and her mum. The best track by my favourite new artist Joss Ryan: Melancholy Dreams Ryan is one of the best new producers I've heard on Soundcloud for a hot minute. He's got a style which is heavily influenced by Joker, Silkie and even James Blake but it's still his own sound. The track that should have been a crossover hit Roska & Jamie George: Wonderful Day How this tune does not get playlisted on Radio 1 every summer I'll never know. The track I wish i'd never played Skee-lo: I Wish I played this on the radio recently. Afterwards I felt pretty depressed. The track I'd play to show off my eclectic tastes Tim Hecker: I'm Transmitting Tonight I also played Bobby Brown's Two Can Play That Game as my last tune at a trance festival. Does that count? The track I'd play at sunset in Ibiza DJ Kent Feat Zaki Ibrahim: Sunrise Even though you said sunset not Sunrise, this would still kinda work. I actually got to play at sunset in Croatia on the Rinse FM boat. I had no idea the sun was setting behind me, so I was playing loads of hard funky and grime stuff. I didn't realise until the pics came back. Never mind. DVA plays Fabric, EC1, Fri; his debut album Pretty Ugly is out on 19 Mar

The track I'll be opening my next DJ set with
DVA: Reach The Sun

I'll be coming on after Untold, so I'll need a long and emotional intro to reset things. If he plays his new tune last, I'll have problems – it's sick.

The track that currently gets the most rewinds
Dismantle: Computation

I've seen people do some cracked-out skanks to this tune. Skream is one of those people. He dances like he's just been electrocuted with 1,000 volts. It's too funny, you should see it.

The track that's been unfairly slept on this year
Funk Bias: Last Forever

I used to batter it! It was released on the Swamp81 label which normally gets a lot of love, but this release just got tumbleweed.

The track that got me out of bed this morning
Shy One: Bedknobs & Boomkicks

It's a project I'm releasing on my label DVA Music. It had me up at 4.30am this morning trying to get her to finish it off.

The track I wish I'd signed to my label
Cher Lloyd: Swagger Jagger

Then I would have made sure that no one else on the planet heard it apart from her and her mum.

The best track by my favourite new artist
Joss Ryan: Melancholy Dreams

Ryan is one of the best new producers I've heard on Soundcloud for a hot minute. He's got a style which is heavily influenced by Joker, Silkie and even James Blake but it's still his own sound.

The track that should have been a crossover hit
Roska & Jamie George: Wonderful Day

How this tune does not get playlisted on Radio 1 every summer I'll never know.

The track I wish i'd never played
Skee-lo: I Wish

I played this on the radio recently. Afterwards I felt pretty depressed.

The track I'd play to show off my eclectic tastes
Tim Hecker: I'm Transmitting Tonight

I also played Bobby Brown's Two Can Play That Game as my last tune at a trance festival. Does that count?

The track I'd play at sunset in Ibiza
DJ Kent Feat Zaki Ibrahim: Sunrise

Even though you said sunset not Sunrise, this would still kinda work. I actually got to play at sunset in Croatia on the Rinse FM boat. I had no idea the sun was setting behind me, so I was playing loads of hard funky and grime stuff. I didn't realise until the pics came back. Never mind.

DVA plays Fabric, EC1, Fri; his debut album Pretty Ugly is out on 19 Mar

webTitle: Clubs picks of the week

fields.bodyText: Beyond The Clouds, London DJ Deep might not be the most inspiring musical moniker, but you can understand the desire of the man born Cyril Etienne des Rosaies to be known as something rather more inconspicuous, especially when his chosen mission for the last couple of decades has been to champion neglected cuts from the darkest recesses of the house and techno vaults. Joining him on this classy bill are three other DJ-producers who defy easy categorisation: Baltimore-born Sheffield-based maverick Maurice Fulton makes haywire house and electro under a dizzying array of pseudonyms ranging from Syclops to Boof; Actress is a gifted London producer who appears to be plugged directly into the Detroit techno mainframe while still sounding utterly unique; and newcomer Hunee is a Berlin-based Korean whose fine 12-inches on Retreat and Rush Hour have already caused quite a stir in the disco/house underground. Corsica Studios, Elephant Road, SE17, Sat Sam Richards Wrong Island, Glasgow Both Wrong Island's name and slogan – "the right records at the wrong speeds since 2007" – give fair warning to more conventional clubbers that what's on offer might not be to their taste, as well as sending a subtle message to those of a more liberal persuasion that this is exactly their sort of thing. Residents Teamy and Dirty Larry have been involved separately with some of the city's most innovative nights, such as Optimo, Eskrima and Smash Team Disco, before launching as Wrong Island and jointly playing out a mix of everything danceable from 80s disco, all the way to modern post-dubstep stompers. Nice'n'Sleazy, Sauchiehall Street, Sat Patric Baird Shogun Audio, Brighton Always a place which likes to celebrate hometown success stories, Brighton is sure to be out in force tonight for the first show this year to be presented by Shogun Audio. Digital, voted Best Small Club last year by DJ mag, is the ideal venue for this showcase night from one of the most consistent success stories in the drum'n'bass world. In its eight-year history, the label has released breaks-based floorfillers ranging from the deep and minimal sounds of Icicle to Spor's tear-out party anthems and the vast majority of points in between. Tonight sees Shogun's co-head honcho Friction topping the bill and playing a stack of dubplates featuring upcoming releases from the label. Appearing for their debut Shogun set are 16Bit with a turn of total dubstep debauchery, while the Prototypes take time out of their studio schedule to come out and play. Spectrasoul and Bringa offer warm-up support and SP, IC3, and Mantmast do the business on the mics. Digital, Kings Road Arches, Sat John Mitchell Mono_cult 5th Birthday, Leeds Evolving comfortably over the last half a decade, Mono_cult has seen its musical remit widened, having left behind the narrow field of minimal house and techno that were its initial impetus. And though it's flitted around Leeds a little, it returns to its original home for tonight's birthday celebrations. Joining resident DJs Brad Mercer, Matt Long and Paul Kaminski will be German producer Henrik Schwarz, who performs a live set, and guest DJ Joy Orbison. The Faversham, Springfield Mount, Sat Marc Rowlands Tief Presents Diynamic, London In the midst of a messy break-up, Hamburg producer Martin Stimming found himself sleeping in his studio, piecing together tracks from samples of coffee percolators and kids' marble runs. The resulting album Liquorice was undoubtedly fascinating but distinctly undanceable. The beats have been reinstated for Stimming's latest EP, Window Shopping, but his live show this week is likely to be a more intimate and emotional experience than your average minimal techno show. Alongside him is his Diynamic label boss Solomun and the chunky electro-house of Holger Behn AKA HOSH. Corsica Studios, SE17, Fri SR

Residents Teamy and Dirty Larry have been involved separately with some of the city's most innovative nights, such as Optimo, Eskrima and Smash Team Disco, before launching as Wrong Island and jointly playing out a mix of everything danceable from 80s disco, all the way to modern post-dubstep stompers.

Nice'n'Sleazy, Sauchiehall Street, Sat

Patric Baird

Shogun Audio, Brighton

Always a place which likes to celebrate hometown success stories, Brighton is sure to be out in force tonight for the first show this year to be presented by Shogun Audio. Digital, voted Best Small Club last year by DJ mag, is the ideal venue for this showcase night from one of the most consistent success stories in the drum'n'bass world. In its eight-year history, the label has released breaks-based floorfillers ranging from the deep and minimal sounds of Icicle to Spor's tear-out party anthems and the vast majority of points in between. Tonight sees Shogun's co-head honcho Friction topping the bill and playing a stack of dubplates featuring upcoming releases from the label. Appearing for their debut Shogun set are 16Bit with a turn of total dubstep debauchery, while the Prototypes take time out of their studio schedule to come out and play. Spectrasoul and Bringa offer warm-up support and SP, IC3, and Mantmast do the business on the mics.

Digital, Kings Road Arches, Sat

John Mitchell

Mono_cult 5th Birthday, Leeds

Evolving comfortably over the last half a decade, Mono_cult has seen its musical remit widened, having left behind the narrow field of minimal house and techno that were its initial impetus. And though it's flitted around Leeds a little, it returns to its original home for tonight's birthday celebrations. Joining resident DJs Brad Mercer, Matt Long and Paul Kaminski will be German producer Henrik Schwarz, who performs a live set, and guest DJ Joy Orbison.

The Faversham, Springfield Mount, Sat

Marc Rowlands

Tief Presents Diynamic, London

In the midst of a messy break-up, Hamburg producer Martin Stimming found himself sleeping in his studio, piecing together tracks from samples of coffee percolators and kids' marble runs. The resulting album Liquorice was undoubtedly fascinating but distinctly undanceable. The beats have been reinstated for Stimming's latest EP, Window Shopping, but his live show this week is likely to be a more intimate and emotional experience than your average minimal techno show. Alongside him is his Diynamic label boss Solomun and the chunky electro-house of Holger Behn AKA HOSH.

Corsica Studios, SE17, Fri

SR

webTitle: This week's new live comedy

fields.bodyText: Julian Deane, London Erudite satire and whimsy is all very well, but there are times in comedy when the only thing that will really satisfy is a load of properly sick jokes. Rising star Julian Deane has plenty at his disposal, part of a deliciously twisted set that never lets good taste get in the way of a big laugh. Deane's a bit older than the average up-and-coming comic, and this is reflected in his wearily cynical outlook on life. Hardly a fresh-faced, perky young performer, he's more like the sour heavy drinker in the corner of the bar, alternately leering at the girls and complaining about his mortgage. Despite this unpromising exterior, he's able to generate a stream of seriously good gags, the kind of quick, sharply written and endlessly repeatable lines that'll always keep a comic in work and an audience richly entertained. Churchill Theatre, Bromley, Sat Dan Evans, London Dan Evans is a properly silly stand-up. You won't find him throwing out well-crafted nuggets of observational comedy or telling a life-changing autobiographical story. Instead, he's more likely to fool around cracking bizarre gags about animals, throwing out endearingly awful puns or telling you how to perform wildly impractical practical jokes. He's very much the comedian as overgrown schoolboy: a lovable, balding imp determined to add a dash of the extraordinary to the everyday grind. And rather than overplaying the wackiness, he balances his surrealism with a down-to-earth delivery that makes the whole package all the more satisfying. While he's not yet had the mainstream TV recognition that his talents deserve, he's an entertaining stalwart of the live circuit, and a favourite with audiences as well with his notoriously hard-to-please comedic peers. Churchill Theatre, Bromley, The George, WC2, Sat; The Spectator, EC1, Thu William Andrews, London If you're a fan of BBC3's excellent sitcom Him & Her, you might recognise William Andrews from his show-stealing turn as a (partially) rehabilitated sex offender. If you have kids you might pick him out as the star of CBBC's take on Monty Python, Sorry, I've Got No Head. Onstage Andrews is wildly experimental and inventive. Previous shows have seen him messing around with all sorts of unusual stage techniques including video and PowerPoint presentations. It's like being bombarded with ideas, most of them inspired, and many very funny. But Andrews is also great when he keeps it simple. Look out for his performances as a deliberately amateurish wannabe stand-up, murdering one-liners as he reads them off index cards; wonderfully imaginative, lightly subversive stuff. You'll find him this week at a one-off spectacular by the Alternative Comedy Memorial Society; other acts include Peep Show star Isy Suttie and Alexis Dubus as revolting French aesthete Marcel Lucont. Arcola Theatre, E8, Tue

webTitle: This week's new games

fields.bodyText: Mass Effect 3, PC, PS3 & Xbox 360 Relieved of command of the Normandy and with Earth in imminent danger from an ancient species of warrior robots intent on eliminating all life from the galaxy, Commander Shepard starts with his (or her, depending on your choice) work cut out. Sent to find help for the faltering defenders of humanity, Shepard's mission is one of shotgun diplomacy, luring, badgering and bribing other species into helping mankind before it's too late. You're offered the option to play as an action game, reducing conversations to non-interactive movies; a story, where conversations become the focus, or as a role-playing game, which is similar to past Mass Effect episodes. The plot is leaner and conversations less sprawling, giving an effective impression of being in your own extended space opera. Like Assassin's Creed: Revelations this outing is the apotheosis of the series' fighting, collecting and conversation mechanics even if its slightly peculiar looking characters and Kate Beckinsale-grade acting wring out much of its emotional impact. Electronic Arts, £49.99 See last week's ME3 feature here Unit 13, PS Vita From Zipper Interactive, the folks behind the unloved and largely ropey SOCOM third person shooter franchise comes Unit 13, another game about military personnel shootin' for'ners. The difference here is that levels have been designed to provide tidy little bite-sized engagements which are ideal for small-screen use. Stealth sections aren't intrusive and even elite missions, where there are no checkpoints and typically only one or two places to recharge your health, initially feel like a pretty well-balanced challenge, testing your ability to exploit its cover-based return fire mechanics. Movement and aiming work well using the Vita's analogue joysticks and the level of aim assistance is better judged than the distinctly wobbly-feeling Uncharted: Golden Abyss. Eventually though, the fun starts to be sapped by brutally spaced checkpoints that regularly force you to repeat lengthy sections in order to progress, a process that after your 10th attempt starts to feel like a repetitious chore. It's a real shame because Unit 13's firefights are undoubtedly the finest currently available on a portable device. SCEE, £34.99 Games news Also out this week are Street Fighter X Tekken (PS3, Xbox 360) as well as a Special Edition, which adds an arcade cabinet money box, comic book and gem power-ups to Capcom's crossover beat 'em-up … The Sims 3: Showtime (PC) lets your Sims take to the stage and tour friends' towns. There's also a Katy Perry-themed special edition … Calvin Tucker's Redneck: Farm Animal Racing Tournament (Wii) is a freakish budget-priced oddity … Jane's Advanced Strike Fighters (PC, PS3, Xbox 360) supplies slightly limp flight simulation for aficionados of the ejector seat, while Stone Quarry Simulator (PC) delivers all the thrills and spills of opencast mining … Finally, the Mass Effect 3 Vault is a themed plastic case for Xbox 360 and PS3, devices that readers might notice already come in perfectly serviceable plastic cases, albeit ones without backlit insignia and a superfluous joypad holder.

webTitle: This week's new singles

fields.bodyText: Liz Green Bad Medicine (Play It Again Sam) Liz stands out from the current crop of solo artists like turning the page of a book of moat-brown carpet swatches to find a pop-up of a giraffe, dressed as Evel Knievel riding a hovercraft over a canyon full of exploding dinosaurs. Unfortunately, that's only a slight exaggeration. With vocals like a phantom gramophone, almost ethereal brass sections and bleakly glorious lyrics, this eerily eccentric lump of assured blues chanteusery is definitely worth pointing your ears at. The Maccabees Feel To Follow (Fiction) Auto-Tune can be a fickle MihiihEEsteResseSSeSS at times. You've written a pretty good song, but not great, needs more ... something. What to do? Cowbell? Ill-advised rap verse? Drown it in dubstep? So many choices. Here, the Maccabees have attempted to rub Bon Iver all over themselves like a thick musky cologne, one that reeks of corduroy and beard detritus. Sadly, they just ended up making the opening vocals sound like Herbert the Pervert from Family Guy gargling a jar of pickled walnuts. Which is a shame, as it merely distracts from what turns out to be a rather nice and pleasantly swirly indie pop wobblealong. Katie Melua It's Better Than A Dream (Dramatico) Katie Melua's back after two unfathomably short years away. So, what treats does nobody's favourite mimsy-jazz squawker and haunted meringue have in store for us? It's standard Melua, a melody as banal as cardboard mist, chewy rhyming couplets, and endless fauxmantic wurbling about doors and illusions and Indian braves, and … lumme, turn it off! It's like someone opened a sodding Hotel Chocolat inside my mind. Paul Weller That Dangerous Age (Island) Paul recently described his new sound as "groundbreaking, maybe, possibly", the important words there being "maybe, possibly". As in: whatever it is that's currently residing on top of Mr Weller's head is "maybe, possibly" a haircut. This isn't entirely terrible. It's nothing new, essentially a blue-eyed soul, Motown, Bowie, Style Council smoothie. Exactly a smoothie, in fact: something your dad might think is bewilderingly modern, but is actually just a load of old smashed fruit. Birdy 1901 (Atlantic) OK, enough is e-bloody-nough. Can we put a lead-lined, torpedo-proof moratorium on tempo-ed down, wibbly-lipped clench-fisted earnest cover versions of, well, anything? It's beyond tiresome now. Here we see internet sensation and relentless caterwauling karaoke foetus Birdy "strip back" Phoenix's jaunty boingabout summer-of-2009 anthem 1901 into a clammy-palmed piano ballad so preposterously bland that, after five seconds, it becomes almost impossible to tell you're listening to music at all. It's bromide for the ears. It's saltpeter for the senses. It's awful. Pack it in.

fields.bodyText: Willis Earl Beal, London The life of an "outsider artist" is genuinely lived on a knife edge. If things go well, you could find yourself like Willis Earl Beal, signed to a quality UK label such as XL. If they don't, you remain a homeless person, shouting. No one's saying Willis Earl Beal is crazy, but the Chicagoan has certainly conducted his young life so far in a fairly eccentric, even movie-worthy (Mos Def is said to be developing a film) kind of way. For Beal, his way to reach out to the world was by leaving flyers requesting friends wherever he went. After a spell spent homeless in New Mexico, he got a job as a hotel porter, in the downtime of which job he taught himself to play. His debut album Acousmatic Sorcery is a difficult listen, but one made easier by Beal's voice. Though untutored, he can "do" blues complaint, soul whisper and even a kind of quasi-hip-hop posturing, all of which he achieves with considerable aplomb. Sebright Arms, E2, Tue John Robinson Public Image Ltd, London However hard John Lydon tries to turn himself into a cartoon, PiL are there to redress the balance and remind the world that beyond the hilarity of his occasional public disgracefulness, he was part of a music that had a darker power. For this, he needed the unique talents of Jah Wobble's bass and the deceptively scratchy explorations of former Clash member Keith Levene, both of whom have lately been touring a "dub" version of Metal Box, the band's second album, without him. This is a development one imagines will further fuel Lydon's ire for his appearance in a reconfigured PiL as part of BBC 6 Music's 10th birthday celebrations. Queen Elizabeth Hall, SE1, Fri JR Diagrams, On tour Not on the surface an exciting group, British folkies Tunng have nevertheless incubated the talent of Sam Genders, who now has an electronic pop band, Diagrams, that recall the warmth of Metronomy. Live, the Diagrams show has become quite a production, swelling the original one-man recording set-up into a nine-piece band. The more the merrier, one imagines. Hoxton Square Bar & Kitchen, N1, Tue; The Cooler, Bristol, Wed; Ruby Lounge, Manchester, Thu; Mojo Bar, Liverpool, Fri JR Tim Berne's Snakeoil, London If the American saxist-composer Tim Berne can be as uncompromising a performer as Ornette Coleman was in his early days, he remains (like Coleman) an improviser with deep jazz roots, driven by the complex polyphonic approach of the late World Saxophone Quartet guru Julius Hemphill. Berne favours stern, repeating melodies challenged by contrary lines of rhythm, dark loops disappearing into gathering storms of drums, quirky private dialogues, and unexpected passages of delicate lyricism. With his remarkable new Snakeoil ensemble, however, he downplays rawness in favour of a contemporary chamber ensemble sound, with the help of the eclectic Oscar Noriega on clarinets, Matt Mitchell on keyboards and Ches Smith on drums. It's a rare balance of composition, improvisation, and an acoustic ensemble's most subtle strengths. Vortex Jazz Club, N16, Wed & Thu John Fordham Jazzwise To The Power Of 15, London It fits the bill that Chris Potter plays the finale of a glittering week of gigs celebrating the 15th anniversary of Jazzwise magazine. Potter's list of illustrious employers, from Charlie Parker trumpeter Red Rodney to bandleading legends Paul Motian and Dave Holland, is like a boiled-down jazz history in itself. Potter's unusual Underground fusion band has been one of his most telling innovations of recent times, but for these two forthcoming London gigs the saxophonist plays with a more orthodox acoustic lineup including the intriguing Steve Coleman, pianist David Virelles and drummer Gerald Cleaver. The week's Jazzwise festival shows also include London fusion trio Troyka with the Royal Academy of Music Big Band (Mon), UK postboppers Empirical and young German piano star Michael Wollny (Tue), and former Miles Davis bassist Ron Carter with pianist Renee Rosnes (Wed & Thu). Ronnie Scott's, W1, Fri & 17 Mar JF Miss Fortune, London It's 18 years since Judith Weir's last full-scale opera, Blond Eckbert, based upon a fairytale by Ludwig Tieck. Folk and fairy stories from a wide range of cultures have always figured prominently in Weir's musical lexicon, and it's no surprise to discover that this new stage work is also based upon a folk tale, this time from Sicily. Miss Fortune tells the story of Tina, a young woman from a wealthy family that suddenly loses all its money. Tina is forced to take on a succession of menial jobs until she encounters Fate and her fortunes begin to change. The production is by Chen Shi-Zheng and Paul Daniel conducts. Royal Opera House, WC2, Mon & Fri Andrew Clements

fields.bodyText: The Devils It's impossible to tell how genuine a controversy is. Were people really upset and outraged by this 1971 Ken Russell classic or was it more to do with organised, semi-professional complainers such as church groups and viewers' associations feeding a press frenzy? Either way, the film still carries enough of a reputation to prevent it being released fully restored (in terms of both quality and content). While that's all rather fitting for a film about mass hysteria and witch-hunting, we're lucky to be seeing it at all, so this very well put-together DVD of the original theatrical version is something to be extra grateful for. Ken Russell had excellent taste, both good and bad. He was one of the few directors to exploit the visual flamboyance of cinema, having little time for the more earthy kitchen-sink concerns of his peers. While based on true events, Russell still made room to be artistic: largely down to hiring Derek Jarman to design the huge, gleaming white sets, presenting 17th-century Loudun as a cross between Metropolis and a public lavatory. As a political statement, the film still has legs; it still looks and sounds contemporary. It's one of the greatest films this country has ever produced, painting in broad, confident strokes with one of Oliver Reed's most powerful performances. The DVD includes documentaries, commentary and an early short film by Russell. DVD, BFI. Out 19 Mar The Help Very well-acted slice of Oscar bait, the performances add the honesty and subtlety the script dearly lacks. Blu-ray/DVD, Disney This Is England '88 Shane Meadows's impressively relentless slice of nostalgic festive misery. Blu-ray/DVD, 4DVD Evidence After a fairly routine opening, this found-footage camping horror completely redeems itself with a reckless and unhinged third act. fields.body:
The Devils

It's impossible to tell how genuine a controversy is. Were people really upset and outraged by this 1971 Ken Russell classic or was it more to do with organised, semi-professional complainers such as church groups and viewers' associations feeding a press frenzy?

Either way, the film still carries enough of a reputation to prevent it being released fully restored (in terms of both quality and content). While that's all rather fitting for a film about mass hysteria and witch-hunting, we're lucky to be seeing it at all, so this very well put-together DVD of the original theatrical version is something to be extra grateful for. Ken Russell had excellent taste, both good and bad. He was one of the few directors to exploit the visual flamboyance of cinema, having little time for the more earthy kitchen-sink concerns of his peers. While based on true events, Russell still made room to be artistic: largely down to hiring Derek Jarman to design the huge, gleaming white sets, presenting 17th-century Loudun as a cross between Metropolis and a public lavatory. As a political statement, the film still has legs; it still looks and sounds contemporary. It's one of the greatest films this country has ever produced, painting in broad, confident strokes with one of Oliver Reed's most powerful performances. The DVD includes documentaries, commentary and an early short film by Russell.

webTitle: This week's new film events

fields.bodyText: Cinema Made In Italy, London Though we don't get to see that much of it here, Italian cinema is still going strong. This renamed festival shows some of the depth, with new films at Ciné Lumière, and older stuff at the Italian Cultural Institute. The new movies cover some familiar Italian preoccupations: organised crime (boxing thriller Tatanka, from a story by Roberto "Gomorrah" Saviano), family (Kryptonite) and coming of age (Summer Of Giacomo). But there are also new angles on Italian culture, such as Li And The Poet, dealing with a Chinese immigrant in Venice, and sci-fi The Last Man On Earth. Many of the films on show are UK premieres, including Scialla!, and there are films selected by the Corriere della Sera's top critic, TV sporting dramas and a tribute to the late Sicilian documentarian Vittorio De Seta. Ciné Lumière, SW7, Sat to Thu; Italian Cultural Institute, SW1, Thu to 30 Mar Flatpack Film Festival, Birmingham This joyously inventive event interprets the notion of a film festival loosely enough to incorporate an evening of psychedelic projections and live space rock, an audience-participation remake of Citizen Kane, a Birmingham Noir walking tour, and a "gif shop" where you can make your own animation and play it on a record deck. Elsewhere, there's puppet animation, cult 1970s cartoon movies with rock soundtracks, new films by Herzog and Kaurismäki, satanist hippies, zombie bikers and even synthpop-producing Icelandic grannies (Grandma Lo-Fi). Various venues, Wed to 18 Mar Shûji Terayama, London Terayama's activities in the postwar Japanese avant garde ranged from film-maker to playwright to poet to horse racing tipster, and subversion seems to have been the only constant. His highly experimental films often took aim at traditional society, and 1971's Emperor Tomato Ketchup details a child revolt against the adult world, with more sex and violence than any film-maker would dare today. The other films in this brief survey are equally confrontational, surprising and bizarre, but in myriad ways – from direct engagement with the audience to surreal imagery to satirising Japan's relationship with the west. Tate Modern, SE1, Fri to 25 Mar 14th London Asian Film Festival, London It's generally only one type of south Asian movie that gets released in the UK but this festival casts its net wider, without excluding Bollywood completely. The presence of Abhishek Bachchan doesn't immediately scream indie, nor does Guzaarish, starring Hrithik Roshan and Aishwarya Rai, but you'll be satisfied by the likes of Michael, a survey of Kolkata lives, or a documentary on Pakistan's persecuted transgender community. Of the safe bets there's the box office-busting Bol, but look out for a fair amount of culture crossing: Lucky, about a South African boy adopted by an Indian woman; and The Desire – A Journey Of A Woman, which details a love affair between a Chinese painter and an Indian Odissi dancer, played by Shilpa Shetty. Various venues, Fri to 24 Mar

webTitle: The Hard Sell: Butlins

fields.bodyText: With flag-wavers set for a summer of Jubilee and Olympic revelry, some Brits will inevitably want to be as far away as possible from even a mere hint of bunting. However, global financial turmoil may have scuppered holiday plans. Like being in a distressingly long version of New Year's Eve, you could end up either broke and stranded miles from home, or keeping up appearances while everyone arrives to party. It's no wonder that this year's campaign for Butlin's is encouraging us to holiday at home. In this latest TV ad, we see a young girl at the Bognor Regis resort bouncing around like Tigger in a Ladybird party frock. Her hops guide us from the upmarket seaview hotel on to golden Sussex sands and into a glistening swimming pool. Butlin's isn't just flogging an idyllic version of its holiday parks here. It's dreamed up a utopian Britain where nobody queues for anything and the weather is Mediterranean. The ad execs must think viewers have never actually seen summer in the country we're living in. A more sincere version would have mum and dad screaming at each other through a bathroom door while the kids play the popular game of "I-Spy (a way we can lose the security deposit)". We'd see scenes of apologetic Redcoats closing the pool as "heavyweight jams" from a recent BangFace Weekender event are cleansed from the filters. Plus, it would royally piss it down over the Bognor skyline. Who needs Club Med? See the ad here

webTitle: Catch-up TV Guide: From Much Ado About Nothing to TOTP2: Girl Groups

fields.bodyText: TV: El Wingador "I was just a guy that liked eating chicken." So begins the story of champion competitive-eater Bill Simmons. Oscar-winning film-maker Errol Morris doesn't do anything fancy with this 10-minute short – it came off the back of shooting a KFC ad – but he really doesn't need to: Simmons carries the load, telling us about his "training" (15lbs of food and three gallons of water a day, apparently), and his inability to ever really be full. On winning the Philadelphia Wing Bowl five times: "You've got to throw some reckless abandonment in and not worry about choking." Grotesque, but great. Online Theatre: Much Ado About Nothing If you weren't able to catch David Tennant and Catherine Tate in Much Ado About Nothing – one of last summer's hottest West End tickets – you can now do so at a fraction of the price and at your own convenience. Caught in high definition with impressive production values, the show can be downloaded or streamed straight to your desktop. There are plenty of other choice stage pickings on offer too, not least Kathryn Hunter's startling turn in Kafka's Monkey, and the underrated Parlour Song by Jez Butterworth, better known for the award-magnet Jerusalem. Online, £6.99-£10.99 Film: Ryan Trecartin online Born in Texas, raised in Ohio, Trecartin is often claimed as one of the most innovative artists working with video right now. His last exhibition – described by the New Yorker as "an exhilarating onslaught" from "the magus of the Internet century" – showed off some of his most hypnotic, bizarre and mind-bending films. You can watch plenty for free here. Online Music: Madonna Live Consider this a warm-up for the First Lady of Pop's upcoming world tour: a full-blown concert archive of all her finest stage moments. Heavy lace and lycra from the 1985 Virgin tour, conical bras and simulated sex from Blonde Ambition – there's little in Madge's live archive that's not here. In short, it's every kind of brilliant. YouTube Talks: TED talks The original TED conference – a bit like a geek Glastonbury of the mind – had its annual outing in Long Beach, California a fortnight ago. All the talks are online and well worth a browse. Try Susan Cain: The power of introverts, Vijay Kumar: Robots that fly … and cooperate, or Paul Gilding: The Earth is full. Online Music: TOTP2: Girl Groups From the Supremes to the Spice Girls, TOTP pays tribute to the glorious ladies (and ladettes) of pop. BBC iPlayer

webTitle: It's a good week for … Guest stars

fields.bodyText: When you're young, nothing's worse than a guest star appearing on a show you love – especially an only-famous-in-America guest star on an American sitcom – because it essentially involves hearing a studio audience whoop at a stranger. But now perhaps we're all better placed to appreciate a good cameo, which is fortunate because we're about to be beaten around the chops with them all week. For example, Weeds (Mon, 10.20pm, Sky Atlantic) has just begun its gradual transformation into Will & Grace, as it replaces everything that people loved about the show with an endless parade of desperate-eyed celebrity guest spots. This week, Richard Dreyfuss dances around to try to stop everyone from realising that the show is at least two years past its best. He doesn't literally dance, by the way. He's in his 60s. Elsewhere, Ken Jenkins makes another appearance on Cougar Town (Fri, 8.30pm, Sky Living) as Courteney Cox's dad, although that's not particularly surprising. Ken Jenkins played Dr Bob Kelso on Scrubs, and everybody who has ever appeared on Scrubs is legally required to turn up in at least one episode of Cougar Town. Except for Carla. Whatever happened to Carla? Greg Kinnear shows up on Modern Family (Fri, 8pm, Sky1) as a man who improbably kisses everyone on the lips, while Patrick Warburton – from everything that's ever been animated over the past decade – finally shows up for a frankly brilliant three-episode stint on Archer (Wed, 10pm, 5*) as Rip Riley, Sky Captain. Not to be outdone, Law & Order: Criminal Intent (Wed, 10pm, C5) has wrangled in Eric Balfour from Dinoshark to play a celebrity chef and Treach from Naughty By Nature to play someone going by the magnificent name of Reginald X Oldman. Unbeatable? Not quite. The Guest Appearance Of The Week award – and the Glee-est Thing That Glee Has Ever Gleed award – has to go to Glee (Thu, 9pm, Sky1), which, in a stroke of uncharacteristic genius, has cast Ricky Martin as McKinley High's new Spanish teacher. Think of something more perfect than that. You can't, can you?

webTitle: Grace Dent's TV OD: I'm A Pop Star!

fields.bodyText: "I thought there would at least be a meeting," reflects Rick Astley on BBC2's I'm A Pop Star! (Sat, 9pm, BBC2), talking of his first Top Of The Pops. "I thought someone might tell me what to wear." Popland in 1987 was a seemingly slapdash affair. One moment Astley is working in Stock Aitken & Waterman's "Hit Factory" wrestling a Rank Xerox toner cartridge and bleaching Pete Waterman's favourite tea mug, the next he's a pop colossus with a No 1 hit. Rick appeared on TOTP in a self-bought, three-sizes-too-big blazer, criss-crossing his arms in a nod towards dancing, merely to fill up the stage. BBC2's Poplife series, covering boybands and girlbands, but now moving on to solo artists, has been warm, thoughtful and watchable. They're smart proof that with a strong narrative, good, funny and candid interviews as well as access to the BBC's vast pop culture archive, straw can be spun into gold. Astley is very funny on his lifespan in pop's rock pool from tadpole to frog-corpse; so too are Craig David, Gary Numan and Nik Kershaw. In fledgling days, snood-wearing 80s pop-minstrel Kershaw did enjoy the benefit of a "styling meeting" before TOTP. "They were paying these stylists so much money I thought … well, I must look really good!" A clip shows Nik on TOTP in a white denim box jacket, white cargo pants, a lemon snood, black wool fingerless gloves and boxer boots, with a Flock Of Seagulls bouffant. It seems that in their early days as wide-eyed ingenues, solo artists usually have a point to prove or an emotional hole to fill. Rick Astley talks of his parents' divorce which left him seeking the limelight; Paul Young had a childhood stutter which vanished whenever he sang; Peter Andre admits to a shrewd plan to become "pop's Jean Claude Van Damme". There's a lovely section on the reality of "promo" work: Gary Numan being marauded by Basil Brush, Sting in battle with Trevor & Simon, Adam Ant flirting with Gordon The Gopher, a chance to win Jason Donovan's breath in a jam jar, and Ronan Keating's dismay at being told to put on a chicken costume at 5am and dance like he bloody well meant it. Of course, following them around are the fans: that legion of relentlessly squeaky, barely menstrual, mainly nonsensical worshippers, lurking in radio station foyers, breathless with inconsolable sobbing about how "happy" they are to have inhaled Shayne Ward's coffee-breath. As the fans lose their minds, so by turn, do their quarry, shifting from "that affable kid who just wants to please" to "Mogwai from Gremlins, fed Krispy Kremes after midnight, then put under sprinklers". Then, just as experience makes pop life familiar and manageable, in a heartbeat, you're not on the guestlist; not even a standby for Hole In The Wall if Joe Swash can't make it. Gary Numan talks of actually missing the hatred in his bad reviews in the 90s: "At least it was attention". Modern-day faded pop stars must feel so grateful for the internet. The internet will always review your decline. It hits you (but it feels like a kiss).

"I thought there would at least be a meeting," reflects Rick Astley on BBC2's I'm A Pop Star! (Sat, 9pm, BBC2), talking of his first Top Of The Pops. "I thought someone might tell me what to wear." Popland in 1987 was a seemingly slapdash affair. One moment Astley is working in Stock Aitken & Waterman's "Hit Factory" wrestling a Rank Xerox toner cartridge and bleaching Pete Waterman's favourite tea mug, the next he's a pop colossus with a No 1 hit. Rick appeared on TOTP in a self-bought, three-sizes-too-big blazer, criss-crossing his arms in a nod towards dancing, merely to fill up the stage. BBC2's Poplife series, covering boybands and girlbands, but now moving on to solo artists, has been warm, thoughtful and watchable. They're smart proof that with a strong narrative, good, funny and candid interviews as well as access to the BBC's vast pop culture archive, straw can be spun into gold. Astley is very funny on his lifespan in pop's rock pool from tadpole to frog-corpse; so too are Craig David, Gary Numan and Nik Kershaw. In fledgling days, snood-wearing 80s pop-minstrel Kershaw did enjoy the benefit of a "styling meeting" before TOTP. "They were paying these stylists so much money I thought … well, I must look really good!" A clip shows Nik on TOTP in a white denim box jacket, white cargo pants, a lemon snood, black wool fingerless gloves and boxer boots, with a Flock Of Seagulls bouffant.

It seems that in their early days as wide-eyed ingenues, solo artists usually have a point to prove or an emotional hole to fill. webTitle: Diary of a separation

fields.bodyText: It's Sunday morning, and I'm in a draughty soft-play centre with punitive acoustics, balancing a foil-wrapped cake in one hand and four pairs of children's shoes in the other: yes, it's birthday time again, our third post-separation, and I think we're getting the hang of it. It's still strange, though, negotiating the cycle of presents, cake and party between two of us. I found myself making birthday cake in a deserted house, following my younger son's terse, bewildering instructions ("monster, green, one eye, red claws, tail with fire") as best I could. In the evening, I took it, and some presents, round to X's house and we all had dinner: me, him, both boys and Anna, the German au pair. All very modern. I hadn't been to the old house for a while and it looks, or feels, different in some indefinable way: the primitive heart of me registers that it smells different; it's not my territory any more. There's a neat bag of matching slippers in the hall and the kitchen is full of Anna's vegetarian stuff – tofu, tahini, aubergines – items never previously glimpsed within these walls. After dinner (aubergine-free), and once the fiery-tailed cyclops cake had been approved by its designer, I read both boys a bedtime story, covertly checking out what was new, altered, shifted: a proper desk for the eldest, bedside lamps I didn't recognise, and our ancient glitter ball finally affixed to the ceiling. As I walked home alone later, I felt bereft beyond my normal sadness at leaving the children. I don't often miss the house but I do miss the certainty, the solidity of it. It feels more like a home now that I don't live there, now I can see it from the outside. Today, a few days later, we're reconvening for the dreaded party, which we've agreed is best got over with in the morning. Consensus on things like that seems easier now. When we were together, birthdays were a battleground, with me pushing for oligarch-style extravagance, and X maintaining that modern children need to learn how to have fun with a twig and a single deflated balloon. Now that there's no financial disapproval to react against (and, importantly, no money), I have scaled down my party ambitions. X picked me up from home and we've driven to the soft-play centre to face the full-frontal assault of 20 seven year olds. "Are you OK?" he says as we're queueing. I have allowed my heavy head to rest against the cool glass of the fire door momentarily. I am terribly hung-over: I went out with my friend Jamie who brooks no dissent in the matter of drinking, and we ended up in a transvestite cabaret in the early hours. I woke up this morning face down in my bed fully clothed (thankfully), with my glasses still on, and things haven't improved greatly since. "I'll be fine." I don't tell him I'm hung-over: we don't talk about what we do outside of looking after the children much. We've developed an odd taboo around the social lives we've developed separately, the people we see and the places we go. Sometimes X shows up to drop the boys off or collect them looking as rough as I feel right now, perhaps mentioning he's hardly slept, but he doesn't give details and I don't ask. On the odd occasions he does mention a bar or a club, I try to picture him there and fail. When we lived together, we didn't really go out: mainly we watched too much TV and ate too many meals on trays. It's harder to do that on your own without the validation that another body on the sofa brings: for me, it doesn't feel like cosy domesticity so much as failure. So we both relentlessly socialise, far, I think, beyond our natural inclinations. After a restorative packet of crisps and can of Coke, the party is fine. It's shambolic, loud and sweaty, but they have fun and we don't lose or injure anyone. X does all the loud, entertaining, nonsensical bits and I do the organising, finding coats and shoes, distributing cake and presents. We make a good team, as always. Afterwards, he drops me and the flushed, over-excited children back at home, kisses them quickly and rushes off. He has somewhere to be, apparently.
